Section.Text: These Regulations may be cited as the Radiation Emitting Devices Regulations.
In these Regulations,

Definition.Text: Act means the Radiation Emitting Devices Act; (Loi)
device means a radiation emitting device that is within a class of radiation emitting devices prescribed in these Regulations; (dispositif)
Minister means the Minister of National Health and Welfare. (ministre)

Heading.TitleText: Prescription of Classes of Radiation Emitting Devices and Standards Therefor

Subsection.Text: The radiation emitting devices described in Schedule I are prescribed as classes of radiation emitting devices for the purposes of the Act.

The standards set out in Schedule II for prescribed classes of radiation emitting devices are prescribed as standards regulating the design, construction or functioning of those prescribed classes of radiation emitting devices and the components thereof.
An inspector who seizes a device or a component of a device pursuant to subsection 10(1) of the Act may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: detain the device or component for such time as is necessary for him to ascertain whether the device or component complies with the standards prescribed therefor;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep or store the device or component in the building or place where it was seized or remove it to any other place for testing to ascertain whether or not the component or device complies with the standards prescribed therefor; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: release the device or component unconditionally or on the condition that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: it be destroyed forthwith or retained by the owner until it is destroyed, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: within a period fixed by the inspector, it be returned

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: to the country from which it was exported, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: to the manufacturer, distributor or importer thereof and be made to comply with the standards prescribed therefor.

Subsection.Text: An inspector who seizes a device or a component of a device pursuant to subsection 10(1) of the Act shall keep a written record of any such seizure, signed by him and setting out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the place, date and hour of the seizure;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person who owns the device or component or on whose premises the device or component was seized;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the manufacturer, the model number and the date and place of manufacture of the device or component;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the place, if any, to which the device or component has been removed; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of the manner in which the device or component has been dealt with after seizure.

Subsection.Text: The person who owns a device or a component of a device seized pursuant to subsection 10(1) of the Act or on whose premises the device or component was seized or an employee or an agent of such person shall sign the record kept pursuant to subsection (2) and shall receive a copy thereof.

Where a device or a component of a device has been released pursuant to paragraph (1)(c) on a condition and the condition has not been complied with, the inspector may again seize and detain the device or component.

Section.Text: Where a court has, pursuant to subsection 16(1) of the Act, directed that a device or a component of a device be forfeited to Her Majesty, and where no application under section 75 of the Fisheries Act has been made or a declaration as provided in subsection 75(4) of that Act is not included in the final order made pursuant to that section, the device or component shall be disposed of as the Minister directs.

Television receivers, including video monitors and video display systems, being electronic appliances designed to display a picture or alphanumeric information, or both, after receiving signals through electromagnetic waves, cable or other means of transmission and including the cabinet or case of such appliances.

Dental X-ray equipment, being radiation emitting devices that are designed primarily for the examination of dental and maxillofacial structures in living humans and that have an X-ray generating tube designed to be used outside the mouth.
Microwave ovens, being appliances or sets of components that are designed to supply microwave energy to material within a cavity.

A baggage inspection X-ray device, being an X-ray generating appliance designed primarily for the examination of carry-on baggage, or the examination of parcels, mail or similar items, including the X-ray generator, the X-ray detector and display and control systems.
A demonstration-type gas discharge device, being a device that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: contains an electronic device in which glow discharges or X-rays or both may be produced by the acceleration of electrons and ions; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is designed to demonstrate the production, properties or effects of glow discharges or X-rays, or the flow of electrons or ions.

Section.Text: Photofluorographic X-ray equipment being X-ray generating appliances designed primarily for the examination of the human chest and the recording photographically in reduced size of the image produced on a fluorescent screen.

A laser scanner, being a device that uses scanned laser radiation within the wavelength range of 400 to 1400 nanometres to decipher or generate codes represented by drawn or printed geometrical patterns.
A demonstration laser, being a device that consists of or incorporates a laser and that is primarily intended to be used for demonstrating the principles of optics in educational institutions.

Low Energy Electron Microscopes being electron-optical devices with an operating energy of 500 kilo-electron volts (keV) or less in which a beam of electrons, focused by means of electron lenses, is used to produce an enlarged image of a minute object on a fluorescent screen, photographic plate or any other detector-display system, including both the transmission and scanning types of devices.

High intensity mercury vapour discharge lamps, being lamps incorporating a high-pressure arc discharge tube with a fill consisting primarily of mercury, whether such lamps are described as mercury vapour lamps, metal halide lamps, self-ballasted lamps or otherwise when sold, but not including tungsten filament self-ballasted lamps.
Tanning equipment as defined in section 1 of Part XI of Schedule II.

Diagnostic X-ray equipment, being radiation emitting devices that use X-rays and are designed for the examination of the human body. The equipment does not include dental X-ray equipment, photofluorographic X-ray equipment, radiation therapy simulators and computer-assisted tomographic equipment.
Ultrasound therapy devices, being devices designed to generate and emit ultrasonic power at acoustic frequencies above 20 kHz for use in physical therapy.
Analytical X-ray equipment, being X-ray generating devices that contain an X-ray tube and that use X-radiation to determine the elemental composition, or examine the microstructure, of material.

Cabinet X-ray equipment, being X-ray generating devices, not including analytical X-ray equipment or baggage inspection X-ray devices, that have the X-ray tube permanently installed in a cabinet and are designed primarily for the examination of material, part or all of which is placed within the cabinet.
In this Part,

Definition.Text: maximum test voltage means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 127 volts, if the television receiver is designed to operate from a 110-120 volt power source, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 110 per cent of the maximum voltage from which the television receiver is designed to operate, if the television receiver is designed to operate otherwise than from a 110-120 volt power source; (tension maximale d’essai)

Definition.Text: service control means a control that is installed on a television receiver by the manufacturer thereof for the purpose of adjustment and that, under normal usage, is not accessible to the user of the receiver; (commande interne)

user control means a control that is provided on or external to a television receiver by the manufacturer thereof for the purpose of adjustment and that for a fully assembled television receiver under normal usage, is accessible to the user. (commande externe)

Subsection.Text: Every television receiver shall be designed and constructed in such a way that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under normal conditions of use, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on failure or malfunction of any one component or subsequent failure or malfunction of other components caused by that failure or malfunction,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: it functions in accordance with the standards of functioning described in section 3 for as long as the receiver has its original components or has replacement components recommended by the manufacturer.

Subsection.Text: Without limiting the generality of subsection (1), the components of a receiver that emit X-rays shall have sufficient shielding to enable the receiver to comply with the standards of functioning set out in section 3.
Where the shielding required by subsection (2) necessitates the use of individual shields, such shields shall either

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be non-removable, or interlocked; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: bear a radiation warning sign that is permanently affixed and clearly visible under the conditions of servicing, and cautions against operation of the receiver when the shield is removed.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (6), every television receiver shall bear on the rear external surface of its cabinet or case, a permanent label that sets out, with respect to the receiver

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the model number;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the city and country of manufacture or a code by which that city and country are identified and the key to which is supplied by the manufacturer to the Minister before the sale of the receiver;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the month and year of manufacture, without abbreviation, with the year shown as a four-digit number;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the brand name of the receiver;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the chassis family designation; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the serial number.

Subsection.Text: The permanent label required by subsection (4) shall be clearly visible at any time.

Where a television receiver is manufactured for sale under the trade name of a person who is not the manufacturer of the receiver, the trade name and the address of that person may, for the purposes of paragraph (4)(a), be substituted for the name and address of the manufacturer if the name and address of the manufacturer are permanently affixed to the inside of the cabinet or case of the receiver and are clearly visible under conditions of servicing.

Section.Text: Every television receiver shall function in such a way that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when the receiver

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is fully assembled,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is used with any supply voltage up to the maximum test voltage,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is used with any settings of the user controls and service controls, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: displays a synchronous raster covering at least 60 per cent of the viewable screen area,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: the emission of ionizing radiation therefrom is such that the exposure rate of X-rays, when averaged over a period of five minutes, to an object having a 10 square centimetre cross section and centred at five centimetres from any accessible external surface of the television receiver does not exceed 0.5 milliroentgen per hour; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the receiver, without its cabinet or case, or any part of the chassis, cabinet or case,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is used with any supply voltage up to the maximum test voltage,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is used with any settings of the user controls and service controls, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: displays a synchronous raster covering at least 60 per cent of the viewable screen area,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: the emission of ionizing radiation therefrom is such that the exposure rate of X-rays, when averaged over a period of five minutes, to an object having a 10 square centimetre cross section and centred at 10 centimetres from the surface of any component of the receiver does not exceed 2.5 milliroentgen per hour.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: aluminum means aluminum that has a degree of purity of 99.9% or higher and a density of 2.70 g/cm3. (aluminium)
aluminum equivalent means the attenuation equivalent of an object, expressed in thickness of aluminum. (équivalent en aluminium)
coefficient of variation means the ratio of the estimated standard deviation to the mean value of a series of measurements, determined by the formula

ImageGroup.AlternateText: The coefficient of variation, determined by the formula “C equals S divided by X bar, which is also equal to one divided by X bar multiplied by, open square bracket, sum from i equals one to n, open parentheses, X sub i minus X bar, close parentheses, squared, divided by n minus one, close square bracket, to the power of one half”.

FormulaDefinition.Text: is the coefficient of variation;
is the estimated standard deviation;
is the mean value of the measurements;
is the value of the ith measurement; and
is the number of measurements. (coefficient de variation)

Definition.Text: dental volumetric reconstruction means reconstruction of the three-dimensional attenuation distribution of all or part of the irradiated volume from a series of two-dimensional projections that are produced by an X-ray beam on an X-ray image receptor moving around the head of a patient. (reconstruction dentaire volumétrique)

deviation, in respect of any parameter of dental X-ray equipment, means the percentage error between the measured value and the value indicated either on the equipment or in the accompanying information. (variation)

digital X-ray image receptor means an X-ray image receptor that has a conversion method which is electrically powered. The conversion method may include single-step direct conversion or multi-step indirect conversion. (récepteur numérique d’image radiologique)

effective image reception area means the part of the image reception area that is configured to receive an X-ray pattern that can be processed for display or storage. (surface réceptrice de l’image efficace)
extra-oral, in relation to dental radiography, means that the X-ray image receptor is located outside the oral cavity. (extra-oral)
hand-held, in respect of transportable dental X-ray equipment, means that the equipment, once it is placed into service, is held in or supported by the hand. (portatif)
intra-oral, in relation to dental radiography, means that all or part of the X-ray image receptor is located inside the oral cavity. (intra-oral)

irradiation time means the duration of an irradiation, measured as the interval between the instant when the air kerma rate rises for the first time to a value of 50% of the peak value and the instant when it drops for the last time below 50% of the peak value. (temps d’irradiation)
lead equivalent means the attenuation equivalent of an object, expressed in thickness of lead. (équivalent en plomb)
loading factor means a factor the value of which influences the X-ray tube load. It includes the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an X-ray beam that is produced by the discharge of the capacitor through an X-ray tube, the X-ray tube voltage and the amount of capacitor charge;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a field emission device in which the emission of electrons from the cathode is due solely to the action of an electric field, the X-ray tube voltage and the number of pulses; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, the X-ray tube voltage and either

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the X-ray tube current and irradiation time, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the current time product. (paramètre de charge)

Definition.Text: mode of operation means the technical state that is defined by a configuration of several predetermined loading factors and other settings for radiography or radioscopy, selectable simultaneously by the operation of a single control. (mode de fonctionnement)
rectification type means the process by which the X-ray generator of dental X-ray equipment converts high voltage to X-ray tube voltage. (type de redressement)

transportable, in relation to dental X-ray equipment, means that the equipment is constructed so that, once it is placed into service, it is capable of being moved from one place to another. (transportable)

X-ray field means the area on a surface that is intersected by a radiation beam whose boundary is determined by the points where the air kerma drops to 25% of the air kerma at the centre of the area. (champ de rayonnement X)
X-ray image receptor means a device that converts incident X-rays into a visible image or into a form that can be made into a visible image. (récepteur d’image radiologique)

Section.Text: The manufacturer, distributor and importer must ensure that all of the following information accompanies each piece of dental X-ray equipment:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacturer’s name and civic address, and its postal address if different;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the model designation of the equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the installation instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any radiological safety procedures and additional precautions that are necessary because of any unique features of the equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: instructions for use that include

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the influence of the main settings or selections that are available to the operator on the radiation dose to the patient,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if protection of the operator is affected by distance from the equipment, information on the impact of distance on the radiation dose, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: all information necessary to minimize the operator’s exposure to radiation;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: maintenance instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for quality control testing to be performed on the equipment, including how often the tests are to be performed and the acceptance criteria;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: for each X-ray tube assembly,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the nominal focal spot sizes,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the cooling curves for the anode and for the X-ray tube housing,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the X-ray tube rating charts, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the focal spot position;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the duty cycles, its rectification type and its generator rating;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the nominal line voltage, the maximum line current and the line voltage regulation that are necessary to operate the equipment at the maximum line current;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the loading factors that constitute the maximum line current condition for the X-ray generator;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the recommended loading factors for each patient size;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: when combinations of loading factors are indicated on the control panel by either a single reference to the combination or the value of only one of the loading factors that makes up the combination, the values of all the loading factors for each combination;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment can operate in automatic exposure control mode,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the accuracy limits of the automatic exposure control,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the nominal shortest irradiation time in that mode, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the reproducibility of the air kerma relative to the range of loading factors, as the loading factors are adjusted by the automatic exposure control;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment can operate in a mode other than automatic exposure control mode, the operating range and the maximum deviation for any setting within the operating range for each loading factor;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment is battery-powered, the minimum state of charge that is necessary for it to operate;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: if removable protective devices are specified for use with the equipment by the manufacturer, information about their effectiveness, application and use;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: if dosimetric indications are displayed on the equipment, information and instructions on how to check and maintain their accuracy; and

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: for transportable equipment, recommendations for secure storage of the equipment against theft and unauthorized use.

Section.Text: In addition to the requirements set out in section 2, the manufacturer, distributor and importer must ensure that all of the following additional information accompanies each piece of intra-oral dental X-ray equipment:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the shape and dimensions of the exit field;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of equipment that has a digital X-ray image receptor,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a description of the minimum performance criteria for the device that is used to display the images for diagnostic purposes,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the nominal X-ray image receptor air kerma range that is needed for the intended use, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: recommendations for typical loading factors at specified distances between the focal spot and the skin to achieve the air kerma referred to in subparagraph (ii);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the method by which the distance between the focal spot and the skin can be determined using the indicator specified in paragraph 7(f);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the air kerma is indicated on the equipment, the maximum deviation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if the air kerma is not indicated on the equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the air kerma at a given distance from the focal spot for every selectable combination of loading factors, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the maximum deviation of the air kerma;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a method to calculate the dose area product using the air kerma and the exit field size; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of hand-held equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: values for the leakage radiation at the operator’s position and the method to assess the leakage radiation,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: guidance on how to avoid image degradation caused by motion of the X-ray source assembly during loading and the methods to assess the degradation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the designation of a significant zone of occupancy, as follows:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: dimensions of at least 60 cm x 60 cm with a height of at least 200 cm,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: a drawing that indicates the boundaries of the zone in relation to clearly recognizable features of the equipment,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: at least one profile of stray radiation in the zone with respect to the height above the floor — under representative operating conditions indicated — and that includes the point that receives the highest dose, and

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: a description of the testing methodology used to determine the profiles of stray radiation, including instructions for achieving the loading factors used in the testing if they are controlled only by an automatic control system.

Section.Text: In addition to the requirements set out in section 2, the manufacturer, distributor and importer must ensure that all of the following additional information accompanies each piece of extra-oral dental X-ray equipment:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the geometric relationship between the focal spot, X-ray beam dimensions, patient position and image reception area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the air kerma is indicated on the equipment, the maximum deviation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the air kerma is not indicated on the equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the air kerma at the entrance of the X-ray image receptor for every selectable combination of loading factors, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the maximum deviation of the air kerma;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum deviation of the dose area product;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: instructions on how to identify the location and dimensions of the effective image reception area;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: for equipment in which any of the loading factors set out in items 1 to 3 and 5, column 1, of the table to subsection 30(1) vary during an irradiation, instructions on how to measure the deviation and on how to compare it with the maximum deviation set out in column 2 of that table; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if a precalculated or measured current time product is indicated on the equipment, the lowest current time product or the combinations of loading factors that result in the lowest current time product.

Section.Text: The manufacturer, distributor and importer must ensure that all information that is required by this Part to be displayed on dental X-ray equipment is set out in a permanent, clear and legible manner on the specified surface of the equipment when it is fully assembled for use.
The manufacturer must ensure that all controls, warning lights and other indicators on the control panel are clearly labelled as to their function.
The manufacturer must ensure that all of the following information is displayed on dental X-ray equipment:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of the control panel,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement that unauthorized use of the equipment is prohibited,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a warning that hazardous X-rays are emitted when the equipment is in use, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: one of the X-ray warning symbols set out in section 8;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on an external surface of the equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of its manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: its model designation,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: its serial number,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the date of its manufacture, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the country where it was manufactured;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on or near the external surface of the control panel — when combinations of loading factors are indicated on the control panel by either a single reference to the combination or the value of only one of the loading factors that makes up the combination — the values of all the loading factors for each combination;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of the X-ray source assembly, with respect to the X-ray tube,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of its manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the model designation,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: its serial number, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the country of its manufacture;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of the X-ray source assembly, the permanent filtration of the X-ray source assembly, expressed at a specified X-ray tube voltage either in millimetres of aluminum equivalent or as the thickness of any other material, together with its chemical symbol;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of the X-ray source assembly, a mark that indicates the location along the X-ray beam axis of the focal spot on the anode target;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: on the surface of any detachable beam-limiting device,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of its manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: its model designation,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: its serial number,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: its quality equivalent filtration, if it is more than 0.2 mm aluminum equivalent, expressed at a specified X-ray tube voltage either in millimetres of aluminum equivalent or as the thickness of another material together with its chemical symbol, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of intra-oral equipment, its exit field size;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of every fixed layer of material in the path of the X-ray beam incident on the patient — excluding any added filters and non-removable materials in the X-ray tube assembly — the quality equivalent filtration, if it is more than 0.2 mm aluminum equivalent, expressed at a specified X-ray tube voltage either in millimetres of aluminum equivalent or as the thickness of another material together with its chemical symbols; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of the X-ray tube housing of hand-held intra-oral equipment, the words

Provision.Text: “WARNING: Hand-held operation increases operator radiation exposure due to proximity. See manufacturer safety information.”

Text.Language: « ATTENTION : L’utilisation de l’appareil en mode portatif augmente l’exposition de l’opérateur au rayonnement en raison de la proximité. Consultez les renseignements de sécurité du fabricant. »

Section.Text: The X-ray warning symbol must have the following characteristics:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it must be displayed in two contrasting colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it must be visible and identifiable from a distance of 1 m;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it must be at least 2 cm high and at least 2 cm wide;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: it must bear the words “CAUTION: X-RAYS — ATTENTION : RAYONS X”; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: it must conform to one of the following:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the X-ray warning symbol:Warning symbol consisting of an inverted triangle that contains a tube with a circle in the middle of it from which three dashed lines emerge.

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the symbol ISO 361 in the report of the International Electrotechnical Commission entitled Graphical symbols for electrical equipment in medical practice, Publication IEC TR 60878: 2015, Third Edition, illustrated as follows: Warning symbol consisting of three black blades around a black circle.

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the symbol ISO 7010-W003 in the report of the International Electrotechnical Commission entitled Graphical symbols for electrical equipment in medical practice, Publication IEC TR 60878: 2015, Third Edition, illustrated as follows:Warning symbol consisting of a yellow triangle bordered by a black line and containing three black blades around a black circle.

Section.Text: The control panel of dental X-ray equipment must have all of the following features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a visual indicator that warns the operator when one further actuation of a control will initiate the emission of X-rays;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a visual indicator that warns the operator when X-rays are being emitted and that is clearly visible during the emission;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment can emit X-rays while not in automatic exposure control mode, controls and visual indicators that enable the operator to select the loading factors or mode of operation before initiation of the irradiation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if more than one X-ray source assembly is controlled by the same control panel, a visual indicator that shows, before initiation of the irradiation, which of the X-ray source assemblies is connected and ready to emit X-rays;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment allows for the selection of added filters by remote control or an automatic system, a visual indicator that shows which filter has been selected;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment is battery-powered, a visual indicator that shows whether the battery is adequately charged for the proper operation of the equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: for extra-oral equipment, an indicator that displays the dose area product; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: for extra-oral equipment, an indicator that displays the air kerma at the entrance of the X-ray image receptor, unless the air kerma is already provided in the accompanying information required by section 4.

Subsection.Text: Every irradiation switch of dental X-ray equipment must enable all of the following functions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to initiate and to end an irradiation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to permit the emission of X-rays only when the operator exerts continuous pressure on the switch;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to operate in a way that it is not possible to initiate an irradiation without first releasing the switch by which the previous irradiation was initiated; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of hand-held intra-oral equipment, to permit the operator to stand at least 2 m from the X-ray source assembly when the X-ray tube is energized.

Subsection.Text: Hand-held intra-oral equipment must also be equipped with a second irradiation switch, whether attached or remote, that gives the operator the option to stand at least 2 m from the X-ray source assembly when the equipment is supported on a stand.

Section.Text: Dental X-ray equipment, except transportable equipment, must have a means to permit initiation of an irradiation by the operator from an area that is protected from radiation by structural shielding or distance.
Dental X-ray equipment must emit a signal, clearly audible to the operator, that indicates the end of an irradiation.
Dental X-ray equipment must have a means appropriate to its rectification type to compensate for variations in X-ray tube voltage that are caused by line voltage fluctuations.
The X-ray tube of dental X-ray equipment must be securely affixed to and aligned within the X-ray tube housing.
The X-ray source assembly of dental X-ray equipment must maintain its required position or trajectory without drift or vibration during operation.

If more than one X-ray source assembly of dental X-ray equipment is controlled by the same control panel, the equipment must have a visual indicator on or near each X-ray tube housing that shows which of the X-ray source assemblies has been selected.

Subsection.Text: Dental X-ray equipment must have radiation-absorbing filters that meet the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the filters must be securely affixed to the exit port of the X-ray tube housing or to the beam-limiting device, or to both; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the filters must provide the following degree of attenuation of the X-ray beam:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for each X-ray tube voltage peak value set out in column 1 of the table to this subsection, a first half-value layer of aluminum that is not less than the value set out in column 2, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in any other case, a first half-value layer of aluminum that is not less than the value obtained by linear interpolation or extrapolation from that table.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(b), if intra-oral dental X-ray equipment operates at a maximum nominal X-ray tube voltage of 70 kV or less, it may have a total filtration of at least 1.5 mm aluminum equivalent.

Section.Text: Dental X-ray equipment that has an automatic exposure control must have the following features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a means to automatically end the irradiation when,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of extra-oral equipment, either

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the product of the X-ray tube voltage, X-ray tube current and irradiation time exceeds 64 kJ per irradiation, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the current time product exceeds 640 mAs per irradiation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of intra-oral equipment, either

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the product of the X-ray tube voltage, X-ray tube current and irradiation time exceeds 3.2 kJ per irradiation, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the current time product exceeds 32 mAs per irradiation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a visual indicator or audible signal to warn the operator that the irradiation has ended because one of the limits set out in paragraph (a) has been reached; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a reset control that must be activated manually once one of the limits set out in paragraph (a) has been reached and before another irradiation under automatic exposure control can be initiated.

Section.MarginalNote: Minimum distance — focal spot to skin
Section.Text: The minimum distance between the focal spot and the skin must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 15 cm, in the case of extra-oral equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 20 cm, in the case of intra-oral equipment.

Section.MarginalNote: Maximum deviation — focal spot to image receptor
Section.Text: If the distance between the focal spot and the X-ray image receptor of extra-oral dental X-ray equipment is adjustable, the equipment must have a visual indicator that shows the distance that is selected and that has a maximum deviation of 5%.

Subsection.Text: Extra-oral dental X-ray equipment must have a beam-limiting device that meets the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when used for dental volumetric reconstruction with a circular image reception area, the device must operate so that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the X-ray field does not exceed the boundary of the effective image reception area by more than 2 cm, measured along any diameter, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: at least 90% of the area of the X-ray field overlaps the effective image reception area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when used for dental volumetric reconstruction with a rectangular image reception area, the device must operate so that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: along each of the two axes of the image reception area, the edges of the X-ray field do not exceed the corresponding edges of the effective image reception area by more than 2 cm or 3% of the indicated distance between the focal spot and the image receptor, whichever is larger, when the image reception plane is perpendicular to the X-ray beam axis, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the sum of the discrepancies on both axes does not exceed 3 cm or 4% of the indicated distance between the focal spot and the X-ray image receptor, whichever is larger;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when used for projection radiography, the device must operate so that the X-ray field does not exceed the boundary of the effective image reception area; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: when used for narrow beam scanning radiography, the device must operate so that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: along the axis of the image reception area that is parallel to the direction of the scanning, the X-ray field does not exceed the boundary of the effective image reception area by more than 1 mm on each side, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: along the axis of the image reception area that is perpendicular to the direction of the scanning, the X-ray field does not exceed boundary of the effective image reception area.

Subsection.Text: Intra-oral dental X-ray equipment must have a beam-limiting device that meets the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the device limits the X-ray field to a circle of not more than 6 cm diameter, measured at the point at which the beam exits the equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the device has an optional means to limit the exit field to a rectangular shape, it must operate so that the rectangle fits inside that circle;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the device has a rectangular exit field, it must operate so that the exit field can rotate with respect to the X-ray beam axis; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of equipment that has an integrated direct digital X-ray image receptor, the device has a means to limit the X-ray field to a rectangular shape that does not exceed the boundary of the effective image reception area by more than 1 cm in the diagonal.

Section.Text: When irradiation times are 0.08 s or greater, the range of settings for the X-ray tube current, irradiation time or current time product of dental X-ray equipment must be in increments that are not greater than the decimal multiples and submultiples of 1.00, 1.25, 1.60, 2.00, 2.50, 3.20, 4.00, 5.00, 6.30 and 8.00.
Dental X-ray equipment that has more than one mode of operation must be constructed in accordance with the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of extra-oral equipment that does not have an integrated direct digital X-ray image receptor, the step size of the adjustment between adjacent settings of the current time product must not be greater than 1.6 mAs; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of intra-oral equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the step size of the adjustment between adjacent settings of the current time product must not be greater than 1.6 mAs, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the ratio of the maximum to minimum current time product settings must be at least 4:1.

Section.Text: For each selectable X-ray tube voltage of intra-oral dental X-ray equipment, the ratio of the maximum to minimum current time product settings must be at least 16:1.
Extra-oral dental X-ray equipment must have primary protective shielding that completely overlaps the X-ray field and that provides the following minimum attenuation:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 0.5 mm lead equivalent, in the case of a nominal X-ray tube voltage of 90 kV or less; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 2 mm lead equivalent, in the case of a nominal X-ray tube voltage of more than 90 kV.

Section.Text: All parts of extra-oral dental X-ray equipment that are located in the path of the X-ray beam between the patient and the X-ray image receptor must, when taken together, have an attenuation of not more than 1.2 mm aluminum equivalent, as determined at the highest X-ray tube voltage of the equipment.
Hand-held intra-oral dental X-ray equipment must have all of the following features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a permanently affixed backscatter shield that has an attenuation of at least 0.25 mm lead equivalent, as determined at a nominal X-ray tube voltage of 70 kV;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a means to prevent unauthorized operation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a means to allow the equipment to be supported in a way that it maintains its position so that it is not necessary for the operator to hold the equipment during operation.

Section.Text: The minimum nominal X-ray tube voltage of dental X-ray equipment must be at least 60 kV.
Dental X-ray equipment must function in accordance with sections 30 to 35 under the following conditions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the unloaded line voltage must not vary by more than 1% of its nominal value; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the line voltage must be regulated so that it does not vary by more than 6% when the line is fully loaded at the maximum rated line current of the equipment.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), for any combination of loading factors, the measured value of a loading factor set out in column 1 of the table to this subsection must not deviate from the indicated value by more than the amount set out in column 2.

row.entry: Irradiation time for extra-oral dental X-ray equipment
Irradiation time for intra-oral dental X-ray equipment
Current time product for extra-oral dental X-ray equipment

Subsection.Text: In the case of intra-oral dental X-ray equipment that has a one-peak high-voltage generator, the maximum deviation set out in item 4, column 2, of the table to subsection (1) does not apply when the irradiation time is shorter than 0.1 s.

For any combination of loading factors of dental X-ray equipment, the coefficient of variation of any five consecutive air kerma measurements — taken at the same point along the X-ray beam axis within a one-hour period — must be 0.05 or less.
Dental X-ray equipment that is internally powered must meet the requirement set out in subsection (1) over the whole range of usable charging levels of the internal supply.

Section.Text: The maximum deviation of the air kerma for dental X-ray equipment must not exceed 50%.
The maximum deviation of the dose area product for extra-oral dental X-ray equipment must not exceed 50%.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), for any selected value of X-ray tube voltage and over the whole range of current time product settings, for any two settings of the current time product that do not differ by more than a factor of 2, the quotients of the average of the air kerma measurements divided by the corresponding indicated current time product must not differ by more than 0.10 times their sum, as determined by the following formula, where X is the quotient of the average of the air kerma measurements divided by the indicated current time product, calculated at each of the two settings of the current time product:
In the case of intra-oral dental X-ray equipment that has a one-peak high-voltage generator, the shortest irradiation time in the range of current time product settings is 80 ms.

Leakage radiation from the X-ray source assembly of dental X-ray equipment must not exceed the following air kerma rate when the equipment is operated at the nominal X-ray tube conditions of loading that correspond to the maximum specified energy input in one hour:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of extra-oral equipment, 1.0 mGy/h; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of intra-oral equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 1.5 µGy/h for hand-held intra-oral equipment, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 0.25 mGy/h for all other intra-oral equipment.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of subsection (1), the air kerma rate must be averaged over a detection area of 100 cm2 — of which no linear dimension is greater than 20 cm — that is 1 m from the focal spot.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Leakage radiation — extra-oral equipment in non-loading state
Subsection.Text: In the case of extra-oral dental X-ray equipment that is not in the loading state, the leakage radiation from the X-ray source assembly must not exceed an air kerma rate of 20 µGy/h.

For the purpose of subsection (3), the air kerma rate must be averaged over a detection area of 10 cm2 — of which no linear dimension is greater than 5 cm — that is 5 cm from any accessible surface of the equipment.

Section.Text: In this Part and in items 3 of Schedule I,

Definition.Text: cavity means a structure that encloses and confines a microwave field; (cavité)
commercial microwave oven means a microwave oven for use

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in a restaurant, cafeteria or other commercial establishment,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in an industrial establishment, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in or with a vending machine; (four à micro-ondes commercial)

Definition.Text: control panel means the portion of the external surface of a microwave oven on which the user controls are mounted; (panneau de commande)
conveyor means a device that transports material into or within a cavity; (convoyeur)
door, with respect to a cavity, means a movable or removable structure that in the closed position is designed to prevent access to the cavity; (porte)

external surface, with respect to a microwave oven, means the outside surface of the cabinet or other enclosure of the oven and includes the plane of any exit or entry port for conveyorized ovens; (surface externe)
interlock means a component or set of components that prevents the generation of microwave power when access to a cavity is possible; (enclenchement)
leakage radiation means any radiation transmitted outside the external surface; (rayonnement de fuite)
microwave means an electromagnetic wave with frequency in the range 0.010 GHz to 300 GHz; (micro-onde)

outer enclosure means a metal or plastic cover that encloses the mechanical and electronic parts of a microwave oven that, under normal conditions of use, are not accessible to the user of the oven; (enceinte externe)
response time means the time period in which a radiation meter indicator reaches ninety per cent of its final steady state reading when subjected to a stepped input signal; (temps de réponse)

service control means a control that is provided by the manufacturer for the purpose of adjustment of the microwave oven and that, under normal conditions of use, is not accessible to the user of the oven; (commande interne)
stirrer means the structure designed to distribute the microwave energy within a cavity; (agitateur)

user control means a control that is provided by the manufacturer for the purpose of operation of the microwave oven and that, under normal conditions of use, is accessible to the user of the oven; (commande externe)
waveguide means a metal tube or duct for transmitting microwave energy. (guide d’ondes)

Subsection.Text: Every microwave oven shall be designed and constructed in such a manner that, under the conditions of use specified by the manufacturer, it functions in accordance with section 4 with its original components or replacement components recommended by the manufacturer for at least

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 200 000 use cycles or openings and closings of the oven door, in the case of a commercial microwave oven; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 100 000 use cycles or openings and closings of the oven door, in the case of any other microwave oven.

Subsection.Text: Every microwave oven shall be designed and constructed to include the following safety features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for each microwave power source, a device or indicator that provides a visible indication of the status of operation of the oven;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a device to monitor one or more of the interlocks required by paragraph (g) that renders the oven inoperable when a monitored interlock fails or is otherwise rendered inoperable;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the power can be varied by a user control, an indicator to show the level of microwave power applied to the cavity;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where a total microwave power generating capacity of 25 kilowatts or more is used, a lock on the control panel requiring the insertion of a key before microwave power can be generated;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where access to the cavity is not by a conveyor, a door constructed and positioned so as to ensure that any leakage radiation does not exceed the limits prescribed by section 4;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a covering or baffle arrangement over any viewing screen, vent or access port in the cavity wall, other than any opening through which conveyor borne material enters or leaves the cavity, that prevents the insertion of any object into the cavity while the microwave power source is in operation;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: where the oven is equipped with a door as specified in paragraph (e), at least two electrically and mechanically independent interlocks positioned so as to ensure that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the door cannot be opened until the microwave power generating component has been turned off, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the microwave power generating component cannot be turned on while the door is open; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: components and shields constructed and positioned so that adjustments to the service controls and user controls to yield maximum possible output do not produce leakage radiation in excess of the limits prescribed by section 4.

Subsection.Text: Every microwave oven shall have permanently affixed to and clearly visible on its external surface the following information and warning sign:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the manufacturer and the model number, serial number and place of manufacture of the oven;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the type of microwave power generating component and the normal operating voltage, operating frequency and normal maximum output power thereof;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the test load prescribed by paragraph 4(3)(a);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the year and month of manufacture of the oven;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the sign described in section 3; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: where the oven is not a commercial microwave oven, the words “NOT FOR COMMERCIAL USE — NON DESTINÉ À UN USAGE COMMERCIAL”.

Subsection.Text: Where a microwave oven is equipped with a conveyorized system, a warning sign described in section 3 shall be permanently affixed to its external surface adjacent to each entry and exit port.

Where the generation of X-rays within a microwave in excess of 2.5 milliroentgens per hour averaged over 10 square centimetres is possible while the oven is functioning in accordance with subsection 4(1), an X-radiation warning sign that is clearly visible while the microwave oven is being serviced shall be permanently affixed to the microwave power generating component.

Section.Text: The warning sign referred to in subsections 2(3) and (4) is a sign that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is shown in two contrasting colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly visible and identifiable from a distance of 1 metre;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has no outer dimensions less than 2 centimetres;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: bears the words “CAUTION — MICROWAVES” and “ATTENTION — MICRO-ONDES”; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is designed in accordance with the following diagram:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: A Warning sign, bearing the words “Caution - Microwaves”, and “Attention - Micro-ondes”, described by an inverted triangle containing a satellite dish emitting a series of lines

Subsection.Text: Every microwave oven shall, when fully assembled and operating with its service controls and user controls adjusted to yield the maximum output, function in such a manner that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the leakage radiation, measured with the instrument prescribed by paragraph (3)(b), at all points at least 5 cm from the external surface of the oven, does not exceed

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 1.0 mW/cm2 with the test load prescribed by paragraph (3)(a) placed

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: in the centre of the shelf in the cavity, in the case of an oven that is designed for cooking and that has a total microwave power generating capacity not greater than 1.5 kW, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: as specified by the manufacturer, in the case of an oven other than an oven described in clause (A), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 5.0 mW/cm2 without a test load, where the oven is operable in such conditions; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the intensity of X-ray exposure, at 5 cm from the external surface of the oven, does not exceed 0.5 mR per hour spread over an area of 10 cm2.

Subsection.Text: Every microwave oven shall, when the outer enclosure is removed and it is operating with its service controls and user controls adjusted to yield the maximum output, function in such a manner that the leakage radiation, measured with the instrument prescribed by paragraph (3)(b) and with the test load prescribed by paragraph (3)(a) in the cavity, at all points at least 5 cm from every mechanical or electronic part of the oven that is accessible to the user of the oven including, but not limited to, the waveguide, cavity, cavity seam, magnetron and magnetron to waveguide connection, does not exceed 5.0 mW/cm2.
For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the test load shall be

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an oven that is designed for cooking and that has a total microwave power generating capacity not greater than 1.5 kW, 275 ± 15 ml of water at an initial temperature of 20 ± 5°C, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of an oven other than an oven described in subparagraph (i), the substance and amount thereof specified by the manufacturer as the load to be used for testing the oven; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the instrument used to measure leakage radiation shall

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: be capable of measuring a power density of 1.0 mW/cm2 with an accuracy of 2 dB or better, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: have an indicator with a response time not greater than 3 seconds.

Subsection.Text: Failure of any single component of a microwave oven shall not cause the interlock system to be inoperative.
The device required by paragraph 2(2)(a) shall have a rated lifetime that is not less than 5,000 hours.
Each interlock required by paragraph 2(2)(g) shall have a rated lifetime that is not less than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 200 000 on-off cycles, in the case of a commercial microwave oven; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 100 000 on-off cycles, in the case of any other microwave oven.

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: detector means the image receptor or other devices that interacts with the X-rays to produce a signal corresponding to the intensity of the X-rays incident on it; (détecteur)

model designation means any combination of letters or figures or both letters and figures by which a device that bears that designation is identified as having characteristics and design features that are uniform; (désignation du modèle)
primary X-ray beam means that X-radiation emitted directly from the target of the X-ray tube and emerging through the window of the X-ray generator; (faisceau primaire de rayons X)
X-ray generator means an assembly of components, including an X-ray tube and its housing and shielding, designed and constructed for the controlled generation of X-rays. (producteur de rayons X)

Subsection.Text: A baggage inspection X-ray device shall be designed and constructed in such a way that it functions in accordance with the standards of functioning described in section 3 for as long as the device has its original components or has replacement components recommended by the manufacturer.
Notwithstanding subsection (1), a baggage inspection X-ray device shall have sufficient shielding to enable the device to comply with the standards of functioning described in section 3.
A baggage inspection X-ray device shall be designed and constructed to include the following safety features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: doors or panels over all access openings that are designed for insertion or removal of baggage, unless the devise is designed to prevent the insertion of any part of the human body into the primary X-ray beam through those access openings;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: interlocking of all doors or panels referred to in paragraph (a), with not less than two independent safety interlocks so that, if any of those doors or panels are opened, X-rays cannot be generated;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: interlocking of all doors or panels that allow access to areas where the exposure to X-rays may exceed the level specified in section 3, except those doors or panels referred to in paragraph (a) so that, if any of those doors or panels are opened or removed, X-rays cannot be generated;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: separate warning lights or other indicators

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that clearly indicate to the operator when the device is powered and when X-rays are being generated,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: designed so that if a pulsed X-ray system is used, the X-rays “ON” lights or indicators remain on for at least 1/2 second, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: that either

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: contain built-in duplication so that the requirements of subparagraphs (i) and (ii) are met, if one of the redundant components fails, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: are interlocked so that, if they malfunction, X-rays cannot be generated;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a lock that requires the insertion of a key before X-rays can be produced and that terminates the exposure when the key is removed;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection 2(4), a control or controls to initiate the generation of X-rays, requiring separate operator action for each exposure;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the automatic alignment of the X-ray generator with the detector when the device is assembled;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: an X-radiation warning sign described in section 4 that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is readily discernible and in clear view of the operator, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is permanently affixed to the device at all access openings where baggage is inserted or removed;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a permanent mark or label that is readily discernible and clearly visible on

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the external surface of the device, under normal conditions of use, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on the external surface of the X-ray generator, under conditions of servicing,

ContinuedParagraph.Text: and that will identify the manufacturer, model designation, serial number, and date and place of manufacture of the device.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph (3)(f) does not apply to a baggage inspection X-ray device that contains a conveyor system if the X-ray exposure, or a sequence of X-ray exposures, is initiated automatically and the device

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: contains a photocell or other baggage sensing device that initiates X-ray exposures or a sequence of X-ray exposures automatically; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is designed and constructed to include the following additional safety features:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a control or switch of a type that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: requires continuous pressure by the operator to maintain the automatic operation of the device, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: stops the conveyor and terminates the X-ray exposure, or sequence of X-ray exposures, when released, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a conveyor of sufficient length to prevent insertion of any part of the human body into any area where the exposure to X-rays exceeds the level specified in section 3.

Section.Text: All baggage inspection X-ray devices shall function in such a way that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at the maximum possible baggage handling rate specified by the manufacturer for the device, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: under all operating conditions of X-ray generation,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the average exposure rate of X-rays, averaged over a period that is not less than 5 minutes, to an object having a 10 square centimetre cross section and centered at 5 centimetres, from any accessible external surface of the device or from the imaginary plane surface that is drawn to close openings of the device, where baggage is inserted or removed, does not exceed 0.5 milliroentgen per hour.

Section.Text: The X-radiation warning sign referred to in paragraph 2(3)(h) is a sign that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is shown in two contrasting colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly visible and identifiable from a distance of 1 metre;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has no outer dimensions less than 2 centimetres;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: bears the words “CAUTION — X-RAYS” and “ATTENTION — RAYONS X”; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is designed in accordance with the following diagram:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: Warning sign, bearing the words “CAUTION: X-RAYS — ATTENTION : RAYONS X”, described by an inverted triangle containing a tube with a circle in the middle emitting dashed lines

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: cabinet of a device means a structure that encloses and confines the X-ray source of the device and the material to be irradiated in the device; (coffret)
device means a demonstration-type gas discharge device; (dispositif)
gas discharge tube means an electronic tube in which glow discharges or X-rays or both may be produced by the acceleration of electrons or ions; (tube à décharge)

model designation means any combination of letters or figures or both letters and figures by which a device that bears that designation is claimed to have characteristics and design features that are uniform. (désignation du modèle)

Section.Text: Every device that contains a gas discharge tube not specifically designed to generate X-rays shall be designed and constructed to include the following safety features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a permanent mark or label that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is clearly visible under conditions of normal use,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: identifies the device by setting out the name of the manufacturer, model designation, and date and place of manufacture,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: indicates the intended polarity of each terminal of the device, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: indicates the power supply or maximum voltage to be used with the device; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shielding that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is sufficient to enable the device to comply with the standards of functioning set out in section 5, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is either non-removable or is so constructed that its removal renders the device inoperable.

Section.Text: Subject to section 4, where a device contains a gas discharge tube specifically designed to generate X-rays, that tube shall be enclosed in a cabinet that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has permanently affixed to its external surface

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the X-radiation warning sign described in section 6,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a readily discernible mark or label that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: identifies the manufacturer, model designation and date and place of manufacture of the device, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: warns that the tube generates X-rays when energized, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the power source for the device is not an integral part of the device, a mark or label that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: is clearly visible under normal conditions of use of the device, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: indicates the intended polarity of the terminals of the device and the power supply or maximum voltage to be used with the device;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is provided with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: two warning lights that are in clear view of the operator of the device, one of which indicates when the device is powered and the other of which indicates when X-rays are being generated, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: shielding that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: is sufficient to enable the device to comply with section 5, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: is not removable or is so constructed that its removal renders the device inoperable; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is constructed so that X-rays cannot be generated by the device when any door or panel in the cabinet that allows access to its interior is opened or removed.

Subsection.Text: Where the power source is not an integral part of the device, the warning light required by subparagraph 3(b)(i) to indicate when the device is powered shall be located on the power source.
The device referred to in section 3 shall be constructed so that, where the warning light required by subparagraph 3(b)(i) to indicate when X-rays are being generated fails or malfunctions,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a duplicate warning light operates when X-rays are being generated; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: X-rays cannot be generated by the device.

Section.Text: Every device shall function in such a way that the emission of X-rays therefrom, under all possible conditions of operation and for as long as the device has its original components or has replacement components recommended by the manufacturer, is such that the average exposure rate of X-rays to an object having a 10 square centimetre cross section and centred at 5 centimetres from any accessible external surface of the device does not exceed 0.5 milliroentgen per hour.
The X-radiation warning sign referred to in subparagraph (3)(a)(i) is a sign that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is shown in two contrasting colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly visible and identifiable from a distance of 1 metre;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has no outer dimensions less than 2 centimetres;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: bears the words “CAUTION — X-RAYS” and “ATTENTION — RAYONS X”; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is designed in accordance with the following diagram:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: Warning sign, bearing the words “CAUTION: X-RAYS — ATTENTION : RAYONS X ”, described by an inverted triangle containing a tube with a circle in the middle emitting dashed lines

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: attenuation means a decrease in radiation intensity caused by absorption and scattering in a medium; (atténuation)
coefficient of variation means the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean value of a series of exposure measurements calculated by using the following equation:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: The coefficient of variation, calculated by the equation “C equals one divided by x bar multiplied by, open square bracket, sum from i equals one to n, open parenthesis, x sub i minus x bar, close parenthesis, squared, divided by n minus one, close square bracket, to the power of one half”

FormulaDefinition.Text: = coefficient of variation
= ith exposure measurement
= mean value of the exposure measurements
= number of exposure measurements;

Definition.Text: collimator means a device or mechanism that limits the shape and size of the useful beam; (collimateur)
effective focal spot means the projection of the focal spot on the plane that is perpendicular to the X-ray beam axis and that passes through the centre of the focal spot; (tache focale efficace)
filter means material placed in the useful beam to attenuate preferentially the lower energy radiations; (filtre)
focal spot means the section at which the anode of an X-ray tube intercepts the electron beam; (tache focale)
leakage radiation means all radiation, except the useful beam, coming from within the housing of an energized X-ray generating tube; (rayonnement de fuite)
useful beam means the radiation passing through the aperture, cone or collimator of the housing of an X-ray generating tube. (faisceau utile)

Section.Text: Photofluorographic X-ray equipment shall be designed in such a way that all controls, meters, lights or other indicators are readily discernible and clearly labelled to indicate their function.
Photofluorographic X-ray equipment shall be designed to include the following features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the control panel, the X-radiation warning sign described in section 6;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a warning sign that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is in clear view of and readily discernible by the operator,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is permanently affixed to the X-ray control panel,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: indicates the possibility of hazardous radiation emission when the equipment is in operation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: prohibits unauthorized use;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: electrical meters or other indicators that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are in clear view of the operator,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are permanently affixed to the X-ray control panel, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: show

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the preset operating kilovoltage of the equipment when used in the phototiming mode,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the preset operating kilovoltage and milliamperage of the equipment when not used in the phototiming mode, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: for battery-operated equipment, the state of charge of the battery;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: separate aural or visual indicators on the control panel that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are clearly discernible by the operator, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: indicate when the X-ray machine is powered and when X-rays are being produced;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where more than one X-ray tube is controlled by one control panel, it shall not be possible to energize more than one X-ray tube at the same time and there shall be

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: at each X-ray tube housing, a visible indicator that indicates when the tube is connected and ready to be energized,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: at the control panel, a visible indicator that indicates which tube is connected and ready to be energized, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: at the normal position of the operator, visible indicators that provide the information required by subparagraph (c)(iii);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: an exposure switch on the control panel of a kind that requires continuous pressure by the operator to complete the circuit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a timer so designed that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: when the production of X-rays is automatically terminated after a preset time interval,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the preset time interval is clearly indicated,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: an exposure cannot be initiated with the timer set to zero or in the OFF position, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the minimum exposure time is not greater than 1/60 second,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: when the production of X-rays is automatically terminated after the integrated radiation exposure to a photocell or similar component behind the fluorescent screen is measured, there is incorporated in the timer’s electrical circuitry

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: an aural or visual indicator that indicates clearly to the operator when the phototimer has failed to terminate the exposure, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: a back-up or safety timer, with a maximum setting of 1 second, that will terminate the exposure in the event of phototimer failure, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: when the production of X-rays is automatically terminated after a preset milliampere-second interval, the minimum milliampere-second interval is no greater than 1 milliampere-second;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a collimator that renders the machine inoperative if a part of the useful beam at the plane of the fluorescent screen extends beyond the useful portion of the fluorescent screen and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: where the photofluorographic X-ray equipment is designed for a variable image receptor size and the target to fluorescent screen distance is variable,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the collimator shall be adjustable, and give a rectangular beam,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the alignment of the centre of the useful beam with the centre of the fluorescent screen shall be within two per cent of the target to the fluorescent screen distance,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: there shall be an apron (providing attenuation equivalent to 0.25 millimetre lead for a 100 kilovolts (peak) X-ray beam of half value layer 2.7 millimetres of aluminium) on a bracket attached to the bottom of the fluorescent screen mounting that can be swiveled into place to protect the patient’s gonad area from the useful beam,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: means shall be provided to ensure that the axis of the X-ray beam can only be perpendicular to the plane of the fluorescent screen, and

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: a light beam generator shall be incorporated into the collimator assembly

Subclause.Label: (I)
Subclause.Text: that visually defines the outline of the useful beam, and

Subclause.Label: (II)
Subclause.Text: that does not permit a misalignment of the visually defined field with the X-ray field along either the length or width of the X-ray field to exceed two per cent of the target to fluorescent screen distance, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the photofluoraphic X-ray equipment is designed for a constant image receptor size and the target to fluorescent screen distance is fixed,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: there shall be a shaped lower leaf or an apron on a bracket as described in clause (h)(i)(C) designed to protect the patient’s gonad area from the useful beam,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the alignment of the centre of the useful beam with the centre of the fluorescent screen shall be within two per cent of the target to fluorescent screen distance, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: means shall be provided to ensure that the axis of the X-ray beam can only be perpendicular to the plane of the fluorescent screen;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a filter that
