Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is securely installed in the path of the useful beam, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: provides attenuation, including inherent filtration, at least equivalent to that afforded by 2.5 millimetres of aluminium at 100 kilovolts (peak);

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a readily visible mark on the X-ray tube housing indicating, to within 2 millimetres, the location on the tube housing of the projection, at right angles to the beam axis, of the position of the focal spot on the target;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: an effective focal spot size of not greater than 1.5 square millimetres for units designed to operate at not more than 150 kilovolts (peak);

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a lock, on the X-ray machine control panel, of a type that requires the insertion of a key before X-rays can be produced and the removal thereof causes termination of the production of X-rays;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: an appliance or other means that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: ensure that the machine is not able to be operated if the target to fluorescent screen distance is less than 100 centimetres, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: clearly indicate the target to fluorescent screen distance to within two per cent;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: means that allow data to be recorded automatically on to each film;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: an interlock on the film holder mechanism that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: prevents more than one film exposure being recorded without resetting; and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: prevents the same film frame receiving more than one exposure;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: means that prevent the use of films of size smaller than 70 millimetres × 70 millimetres; and

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: on or near the power-input socket, a statement of power requirements at the maximum line current and, for battery operated units, a statement of charge-use frequency.

Subsection.Text: Photofluorographic X-ray equipment shall be constructed in such a way that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the X-ray tube is securely fixed and correctly aligned within the tube housing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the X-ray tube head maintains its exposure position without drift, tipping or vibration during operation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment, under normal conditions of use, functions in accordance with the standards described in section 5 for as long as the X-ray machine has its original components or replacement components recommended by the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where there is provision for insertion of a grid, there is a holder containing a label that indicates the grid ratio of the grid used;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: mirrors, lenses or other optical components within the camera hood are securely fastened so that optical misalignment cannot occur with normal use;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the camera hood, containing the whole optical system, does not admit light that can fog the film;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any material between the film side of the fluorescent screen and the first optical component does not reduce the light intensity or alter the spectrum of the light emitted from the fluorescent screen;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the front panel at the camera hood, located between the patient and the fluorescent screen, has less than 0.5 millimetre aluminium equivalence measured with an X-ray beam of potential 100 kilovolts (peak) with a half value layer of 2.7 millimetres of aluminium;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the device bears a replaceable label mounted on the camera hood in clear view of the operator, indicating the type and date of insertion of the fluorescent screen; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: when the recommended schedule of maintenance for the device is followed, the device will function in accordance with section 5 for the normal lifetime of the device.

Subsection.Text: Photofluorographic X-ray equipment shall bear, on the tube housing and on the control panel, a permanent mark or label that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly visible; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: carries, with reference to the X-ray machine and X-ray tube, the name of the manufacturer, the model number, the serial number and the date and place of manufacture.

Section.Text: Photofluorographic X-ray equipment when fully assembled for use shall function under normal conditions of use in such a way that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is not possible to preset the kilovoltage below 70 kilovolts (peak);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the preset kilovoltage of the X-ray tube is maintained or is adjustable to within 3 kilovolts when the line voltage supply varies by plus or minus 10 per cent of its nominal value;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for any combination of kilovoltage, current and time, the coefficient of variation of any 10 consecutive radiation exposures, taken at the same distance within a time period of 1 hour, is no greater than 0.05;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the entrance exposure to a sheet of 99.9 per cent pure copper of dimensions 45 centimetres × 45 centimetres × 1.41 millimetres, placed over the front panel, and phototimed with the exposure taken at 85 kilovolts (peak), does not exceed 50 milliroentgens per exposure to obtain at the centre of the film an optical density above gross fog of not less than 0.5;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: at any fixed kilovoltage, the average ratios of milliroentgen exposure to milliampere-seconds obtained at any two consecutive tube current settings do not differ by more than 0.10 times their sum, namely,

FormulaDefinition.Text: are the average milliroentgen per milliampere-second values obtained at each of two consecutive tube current settings;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the leakage radiation from the X-ray tube assembly, when the machine is operated at any kilovoltage and current within the rating of the X-ray tube, is such that the average exposure rate of X-rays to any object having a 100 square centimetre cross-section and centred at 1 metre from the focal spot of the X-ray tube does not exceed 100 milliroentgens in 1 hour; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: emission of ionizing radiation by any component other than the X-ray tube assembly, when the machine is operated at any kilovoltage and current within the rating of the X-ray tube, is such that the average exposure rate of X-rays to any object having a 10 square centimetre cross-section and centred at 5 centimetres from any accessible surface of the device, does not exceed 2.5 milliroentgens per hour.

Section.Text: The X-radiation warning sign referred to in section 3 of this Part is a sign that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is shown in two contrasting colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly visible and identifiable from a distance of 1 metre;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has no outer dimensions less than 2 centimetres;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: bears the words “CAUTION X-RAYS” and “ATTENTION RAYONS X”; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is designed in accordance with the following diagram:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: Warning sign, bearing the words “CAUTION: X-RAYS — ATTENTION : RAYONS”, described by an inverted triangle containing a tube with a circle in the middle emitting dashed lines

Section.Text: In this Part and in item 7 of Schedule I,

Definition.Text: accessible location means any point that can be reached by any part of the human body; (point accessible)
exit aperture means an opening or window in the protective enclosure of a laser scanner that is designed to allow laser radiation to be transmitted to the outside; (ouverture de sortie)
integrated irradiance means the radiant energy incident per unit area of surface expressed as joules per square centimetre (J cm-2); (exposition énergétique (dose))
irradiance means radiant power incident per unit area expressed as watts per square centimetre (W cm-2); (éclairement énergétique)
laser means any device that can be made to produce light primarily by the process of stimulated emission; (laser)
laser radiation means all electromagnetic radiation generated by a laser that is coherent and propagates collinearly through space; (rayonnement laser)
protective enclosure means a structure that encloses a laser scanner and its accessory components and restricts the emission of laser radiation to one or more exit apertures; (parois protectrices)
protective housing means a structure that encloses the components of a laser and prevents the emission of laser radiation except through an exit aperture; (logement protecteur)
pulse means an intermittent emission of laser radiation for a duration of less than 0.25 second; (impulsion)
pulse duration means the time interval measured between the half-peak power points on the leading and trailing edges of a pulse; (durée d’impulsion)
safety interlock means a mechanism that prevents the generation of radiation when any portion of the protective enclosure is removed or displaced; (enclenchement de sécurité)
scanned laser radiation means laser radiation having a time varying direction, origin or pattern of propagation with respect to a stationary frame of reference; (rayonnement laser balayeur)

service controls means controls that are provided by the manufacturer for the purpose of adjustment of the laser scanner and that, under normal conditions of use, are not accessible to the user of the laser scanner; (commandes internes)

user controls means controls that are provided by the manufacturer for the purpose of operation of the laser scanner and that, under normal conditions of use, are accessible to the user of the laser scanner; (commandes externes)
wavelength means a wavelength in vacuo. (longueur d’onde)

Subsection.Text: Every laser scanner shall be designed and constructed in such a manner that, under the conditions of use specified by the manufacturer, it functions in accordance with section 4 so long as its original components or replacement components recommended by the manufacturer are in use.
Every laser scanner shall be designed in such a way that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all marks, labels and signs are permanently affixed and clearly visible; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all controls, meters, lights or other indicators are readily discernible and clearly labelled to indicate their function.

Subsection.Text: Every laser scanner shall have on its external surface the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the distributor, if the distributor is other than the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the model designation, the serial number and the month and year of manufacture;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for pulsed lasers, the energy per pulse, pulse duration and pulse repetition rate;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: for non-pulsed lasers, the output power; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the manufacturer of the laser or lasers used in the device.

Subsection.Text: Every laser scanner shall be designed and constructed to include the following safety features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a switch or other control by which the laser scanner may be turned ON and OFF;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a protective housing;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a protective enclosure;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a safety interlock or interlocks; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if means are provided to defeat or bypass interlocks for maintenance purposes,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a visual or aural indication when any interlock is defeated or bypassed, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the replacement of any removed or displaced portion of the protective enclosure is not possible when the interlock or interlocks are defeated or bypassed.

Subsection.Text: Every laser scanner shall be designed and constructed in such a way that failure or malfunction of any component of the scanner does not result in leakage of laser radiation in excess of the limits specified in section 4.

Every laser scanner shall have the laser radiation warning sign described in section 5 permanently affixed to appropriate surfaces inside the scanner so as to be clearly visible under conditions of removal or displacement of each removable or displaceable portion of the protective enclosure.

Section.Text: Every laser scanner shall be equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an operation manual that contains instructions for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the installation,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the operation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the detection of any malfunction of the laser scanner; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a servicing manual that contains

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: details of the electronic and mechanical control systems,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: instructions for service adjustments and service procedures including warnings or precautions to be taken to avoid possible exposure to laser radiation or other electromagnetic radiations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a schedule of maintenance requirements that, if followed, will maintain the safety features indicated in paragraphs 2(4)(a) to (e) and keep the scanner functioning in accordance with section 4 during the normal operation and normal lifetime of the scanner.

Section.Text: Every laser scanner, when fully assembled and operating with its service controls and user controls adjusted to yield the maximum emission, shall function in such a manner that the intensity of laser radiation at all accessible locations, when measured within a stationary circular area of 0.385 square centimetres and averaged over that area does not exceed the following limits:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: during any time interval of less than 1.8 × 10-5 seconds, an integrated irradiance of 5.0 × 10-7 joules per square centimetre;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: during any time interval, t seconds, that is greater than 1.8 × 10-5 seconds but less than or equal to 10 seconds, an integrated irradiance of 1.8 × 10-3 t0.75 joules per square centimetre;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: during any time interval of greater than 10 seconds but less than or equal to 1.0 × 104 seconds, an integrated irradiance of 1.0 × 10–2 joules per square centimetre; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: during any time interval of greater than 1.0 × 104 seconds, an irradiance of 1.0 × 10–6 watts per square centimetre.

Section.Text: The laser radiation warning sign referred to in subsection 2(6) is a sign that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is shown in two contrasting colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly visible and identifiable from a distance of 1 metre;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has no outer dimension less than 2 centimetres;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: bears the words “CAUTION — HAZARDOUS LASER AND ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION WHEN OPEN AND INTERLOCK DEFEATED” — “ATTENTION — RAYONNEMENT LASER ET ELECTROMAGNÉTIQUE DANGEREUX SI OUVERT AVEC L’ENCLENCHEMENT DE SÉCURITÉ ANNULÉ”; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is designed in accordance with the following diagram:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: Warning sign, bearing the words “Caution - Hazardous laser and electromagnetic radiation when open and interlock defeated” — “Attention - Rayonnement laser et electromagnétique dangereux si ouvert avec l’enclenchement de sécurité annulé”, consisting of an inverted triangle containing a spark with a line attached going to the top right corner.

Section.Text: In this Part and in item 8 of Schedule I,

Definition.Text: beam means a collection of rays that may be parallel, convergent or divergent; (faisceau)

diameter, with respect to a laser beam, means the minimum diameter of a circular aperture that, when placed to intercept the beam with the plane of the circular aperture perpendicular to the direction of propagation of the beam, will permit 0.865 of the total beam power to be transmitted; (diamètre)
divergence, with respect to a laser beam, means the full angle of spread of the beam; (divergence)
exit aperture means an opening or window in the protective housing of a demonstration laser that is designed to allow laser radiation to be transmitted to the outside; (ouverture de sortie)

kit, with respect to a demonstration laser, means a set of components that, when assembled in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions, will result in a demonstration laser; (ensemble en pièces détachées)
laser means any device that can be made to produce light primarily by the process of stimulated emission; (laser)
laser radiation means all electromagnetic radiation generated by a laser that is coherent and propagates collinearly through space; (rayonnement laser)
lasing medium means a material that emits laser radiation by virtue of stimulated transitions between specific electronic or molecular energy levels; (matière active)
protective housing means a structure that encloses the components of a demonstration laser and prevents the emission of laser radiation except through an exit aperture; (logement protecteur)
shutter means a mechanism that, in its closed position, intercepts the laser beam and prevents the emission of laser radiation from the demonstration laser; (obturateur)
wavelength means a wavelength in vacuo. (longueur d’onde)

Subsection.Text: Every demonstration laser shall be designed and constructed to include the following safety features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a switch or control by which the device may be turned ON and OFF;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a protective housing the removal of which renders the laser inoperable;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an indicator, other than the laser beam, that indicates visually or aurally when

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the laser is in operation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the shutter required by paragraph (d) is open; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a permanently attached shutter.

Subsection.Text: Every demonstration laser shall have permanently affixed and clearly visible on its external surface the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the model designation, serial number, and the year and month of manufacture;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the distributor, if the distributor is other than the manufacturer of the device;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the type of lasing medium;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum laser radiation output power, in milliwatts;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the wavelength of the laser radiation, in nanometres;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the diameter of the laser beam at the exit aperture, in millimetres;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the divergence of the laser beam, in milliradians; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the laser radiation warning sign described in section 5.

Section.Text: Every demonstration laser shall be equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: instructions for the safe operation and use of the device including warnings or precautions to be taken to avoid hazardous exposure to laser radiation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a schedule of maintenance requirements that, if followed, will maintain the safety features indicated in paragraphs 2(1)(a) to (d) in a good state of repair and keep the device functioning in accordance with section 4; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the device is in the form of a kit, a set of instructions setting out the step-by-step procedure for assembly and testing to ensure that all the requirements of these Regulations are met.

Subsection.Text: Every demonstration laser shall function in such a way that the laser radiation emission

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: does not exceed 1 milliwatt under all possible conditions of use; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is within the wavelength range from 400 nanometres to 780 nanometres.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of subsection (1), the instrument used for the measurement of laser radiation emission shall have a circular aperture with a diameter of at least 7 millimetres.

Section.Text: For the purpose of paragraph 2(2)(i), the laser radiation warning sign described in this section is a sign that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is shown in two contrasting colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly visible and identifiable from a distance of 1 metre;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has no outer dimensions less than 2 centimetres;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: bears the words “CAUTION LASER, TO AVOID EYE DAMAGE DO NOT LOOK INTO BEAM — ATTENTION LASER, POUR ÉVITER DES DOMMAGES AUX YEUX NE PAS REGARDER DANS LE FAISCEAU”; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is designed in accordance with the following diagram:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: Warning sign, bearing the words “CAUTION LASER, TO AVOID EYE DAMAGE DO NOT LOOK INTO BEAM — ATTENTION LASER, POUR ÉVITER DES DOMMAGES AUX YEUX NE PAS REGARDER DANS LE FAISCEAU”, consisting of an inverted triangle containing a spark with a line attached going to the top right corner.

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: service control means a control that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is installed by the manufacturer on a low energy electron microscope or on any accessory thereof for the purpose of adjustment, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: under normal conditions of use, is not accessible to the user; (commande interne)

Definition.Text: user control means a control that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is provided by the manufacturer on a low energy electron microscope or on any accessory thereof for the purpose of adjustment, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a fully assembled low energy electron microscope under normal conditions of use, is accessible to the user. (commande externe)

Section.Text: Every low energy electron microscope shall be designed in such a way that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all marks, labels and signs are permanently affixed and clearly visible;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all user controls, meters, lights or other indicators are readily discernible and clearly labelled as to function; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it bears on the external surface

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a mark or label that sets out with respect to the device

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the name and address of the manufacturer,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the model designation,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the serial number, and

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: the date of manufacture, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the X-radiation warning sign described in section 6.

Section.Text: Every low energy electron microscope shall be designed and constructed in such a way that it functions in accordance with the standards of functioning described in section 5 for as long as the device has its original components or has replacement components recommended by the manufacturer.
Every low energy electron microscope shall be designed and constructed to include the following safety features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shielding, if necessary, that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is sufficient to enable the device to comply with the standards of functioning set out in section 5, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is either non-removable or is so constructed or connected that its removal renders the device inoperable;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any door or panel that allows access to areas where the exposure to X-rays may exceed the level specified in section 5 is connected in such a way that, if that door or panel is opened or removed, the device cannot function;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: accessory ports, if any, are provided with shielded covers that are interlocked in such a way that, if a cover is removed, the device cannot function unless the accessory for which the port is intended is in place;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any accessory provided with or intended for use with the device is shielded in accordance with paragraph (a).

Section.Text: Every low energy electron microscope shall function in such a way that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at all settings of the user controls and service controls, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: under all possible modes of operation,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: the exposure rate of X-rays to an object having a 10 square centimetre cross section and centred at 5 centimetres from any accessible external surface of

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the device, and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any accessory provided for use with the device,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: does not exceed 0.5 milliroentgen per hour.

Section.Text: The X-radiation warning sign referred to in paragraph 2(c) is a sign that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is shown in two contrasting colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly visible and identifiable from a distance of 1 metre;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has no outer dimensions less than 2 centimetres;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: bears the words “CAUTION, X-RAYS” and “ATTENTION, RAYONS X”; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is designed in accordance with the following diagram:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: Warning sign, bearing the words “Caution: X-Rays — Attention: Rayons X”, described by an inverted triangle containing a tube with a circle in the middle emitting dashed lines

Heading.Label: PART X
Heading.TitleText: High Intensity Mercury Vapour Discharge Lamps

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: cumulative operating time means the sum of the periods of time during which electric current passes through the high-pressure arc discharge tube of a lamp; (durée cumulée de fonctionnement)
lamp means any high intensity mercury vapour discharge lamp; (lampe)

lamp container means a carton, wrapper or other package in which a lamp is shipped, stored or displayed, and that bears information concerning the identification or use of the lamp it contains; (conteneur de lampe)

outer envelope means the exterior shell, usually glass, surrounding a high-pressure arc discharge tube that attenuates the emission of shortwave ultraviolet radiation when intact; (enveloppe extérieure)
self-extinguishing lamp means a lamp

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: manufactured after March 7, 1980, that, when tested in accordance with section 6, ceases operation within a cumulative operating time not exceeding 15 minutes following the puncturing or the complete breakage of the outer envelope except where fragments of the breakage extend 50 mm or less from the base shell, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: manufactured after September 7, 1981, that, when tested in accordance with section 6, ceases operation within a cumulative operating time not exceeding 15 minutes following the puncturing of the outer envelope or the breakage of at least 3 square cm of the outer envelope; (lampe à auto-extinction)

Definition.Text: shortwave ultraviolet radiation means ultraviolet radiation having wavelengths shorter than 320 nanometres. (rayonnement ultraviolet court)

Section.Text: Every lamp shall have the name of the manufacturer and the month and year of its manufacture

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: imprinted thereon, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: set out in a label permanently attached thereto

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: in such a manner that the information is legible whether the lamp is intact or its outer envelope is broken or removed.

Section.Text: Every self-extinguishing lamp shall bear the letter “T” clearly marked on its outer envelope and on its base.
Every lamp other than a self-extinguishing lamp shall bear the letter “R” clearly marked on its outer envelope and on its base.

Subsection.Text: Every lamp container of a self-extinguishing lamp shall bear, in a clear and prominent manner,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the letter “T”; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a statement in English and in French to the following effect:

Provision.Text: “This lamp should self-extinguish within 15 minutes after the outer envelope is broken or punctured. If such damage to the outer envelope occurs, TURN OFF AND REMOVE LAMP to avoid possible injury from hazardous shortwave ultraviolet radiation.”.

Subsection.Text: Every lamp container of a lamp other than a self-extinguishing lamp shall bear, in a clear and prominent manner,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the letter “R”; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the words “WARNING — MISE EN GARDE” followed by a statement in English and French to the following effect:

Provision.Text: “This lamp can cause serious skin burn and eye inflammation from shortwave ultraviolet radiation if the outer envelope of the lamp is broken or punctured. Do not use where people will remain for more than a few minutes unless adequate shielding or other safety precautions are used. Lamps that will automatically extinguish when the outer envelope is broken or punctured are commercially available.”.

Section.Text: To determine whether a lamp is a self-extinguishing lamp, the lamp shall be tested as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the lamp voltage, current and fixture shall be those indicated or recommended by the manufacturer for the operation of the lamp while undamaged;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where there is no indication or recommendation by the manufacturer referred to in paragraph (a) respecting the fixture, the lamp shall be tested with no reflector or other surrounding material;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the lamp shall be started and operated on a reference ballast;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the lamp shall be started in air that has a temperature of 25± 5°C and any heating or movement of the air surrounding the lamp after the test has commenced shall be that produced by the lamp and ballast alone; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if any test is performed in an enclosure, the enclosure shall not be less than 0.227 cubic metre.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: double-contact medium screw lampholder means a lampholder described in the International Electrotechnical Commission Standard IEC 60061-2, Edition 3.41, 2010-04, Sheet 7005-29-2, entitled Position of holder thread in relation to the central and intermediate contacts of the lampholder E26d, as amended from time to time. (douille à contact double pour vis moyenne)

erythema reference action spectrum means the erythema action spectrum set out in section 5.2 of the International Commission on Illumination Standard ISO 17166:1999(E) / CIE S 007/E-1998, first edition, entitled Erythema reference action spectrum and standard erythema dose, as amended from time to time. (spectre d’action érythémale de référence)

exposure position means any place, orientation or distance relative to the ultraviolet-radiating surface of tanning equipment at which it is recommended by the manufacturer that the user be exposed. (position pendant l’exposition)

exposure schedule means a program of exposure recommended by the manufacturer of tanning equipment that takes into account exposure times, intervals between exposures and the degree of sensitivity for each skin type. (programme d’expositions)
irradiance means radiant power incident per unit area, expressed in watts per square metre (W/m2). (éclairement énergétique)
maximum exposure time means the longest period for continuous exposure recommended by the manufacturer of tanning equipment. (durée maximale d’exposition)

protective eyewear means a device that is worn by the user of tanning equipment to reduce the ultraviolet radiation reaching their eyes either directly or indirectly. (dispositif de protection des yeux)

single-contact medium screw lampholder means a lampholder described in the International Electrotechnical Commission Standard IEC 60061-2, Edition 3.41, 2010-04, Sheet 7005-21A-1, entitled Lampholders E26, as amended from time to time. (douille à contact unique pour vis moyenne)

spectral irradiance means the irradiance that results from radiation within an infinitesimally small wavelength range, expressed in watts per square metre per nanometre (W/m2/nm). (éclairement énergétique spectral)

spectral transmittance means the ratio of the spectral irradiance that is transmitted through protective eyewear to the spectral irradiance that is incident and normal to the surface of the eyewear. (transmittance spectrale)
tanning equipment means a device that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: can be equipped with one or more ultraviolet lamps; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: induces skin tanning or other cosmetic effects.

ContinuedDefinition.Text: It does not include any such device that is used in the production of therapeutic effects for medical purposes. (appareil de bronzage)

Definition.Text: timer means a device that is capable of ending the emission of ultraviolet radiation from tanning equipment after a preset period. (minuterie)
ultraviolet lamp means a device that produces ultraviolet radiation in the wavelength range from 200 nm to 400 nm and is used in tanning equipment. (lampe à rayonnements ultraviolets)
wavelength means a wavelength as measured in air. (longueur d’onde)

Section.Text: The information and labels required by this Part must be provided in both official languages.
The following information must accompany each piece of tanning equipment:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: instructions for its operation and safe use that include

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: detailed directions for determining the exposure positions,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the maximum exposure time,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the minimum interval between consecutive exposures recommended by the manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the maximum number of persons who may, at the same time, be exposed to ultraviolet radiation from the tanning equipment, as recommended by the manufacturer, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the ultraviolet radiation warning labels described in section 5;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: instructions for obtaining repairs and the recommended replacement components and accessories that comply with the requirements of these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a warning to always follow the instructions that accompany the equipment so as to avoid injury.

Section.Text: Every piece of tanning equipment must have permanently affixed to its external surface the following information, clearly legible and readily accessible to view by the user immediately before use:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacturer’s name and address;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the model designation, serial number and month and year of manufacture;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: detailed directions for determining the exposure positions and a warning that the use of any other position may result in overexposure;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the recommended exposure time, as calculated in seconds using the formula

FormulaGroup.FormulaConnector: and converted into and expressed in minutes, where

FormulaDefinition.Text: is a dose not greater than 100 J/m2 for the first exposure session for untanned skin, gradually increasing over the following sessions to a maximum of 625 J/m2 per session,
is the wavelength in nanometers,
is the irradiance of the tanning equipment, measured at the minimum exposure distance, and
is the weighting factor determined in accordance with the erythema reference action spectrum;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the minimum interval between consecutive exposures;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum number of minutes of exposure per year, as recommended by the manufacturer based on a maximum annual dose of 15 kJ/m2, weighted in accordance with the erythema reference action spectrum and taking into account the recommended exposure schedule;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the model designation for each type of ultraviolet lamp that is to be used in the tanning equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the ultraviolet radiation warning labels designed in accordance with section 5.

Section.Text: The ultraviolet radiation warning labels must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be reproduced from the electronic file provided by the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: include in the French version of the label illustrated in Figure 1 of paragraph (e), enclosed within a black border,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the upper portion, on a white background, the signal word “Danger” in red with the hazard symbol to its right,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the middle portion, the primary hazard statement “Les appareils de bronzage peuvent causer le cancer” in yellow on a black background,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the lower left portion, the following statements in black on a white background and in the following order:

Provision.Text: “L’exposition aux rayonnements ultraviolets (UV) peut avoir des effets nocifs sur la santé :”
“• La surexposition provoque des brûlures aux yeux et à la peau”
“• Les effets des UV sont cumulatifs et peuvent être cancérogènes — plus l’exposition régulière commence tôt, plus les risques qui y sont associés sont élevés”
“• Les facteurs de risque comprennent le type de peau, la photosensibilité et les antécédents de cancer de la peau”
“• Les médicaments et les cosmétiques peuvent augmenter les effets des UV”,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: in the lower right portion, the following statements in black on a white background and in the following order:

Provision.Text: “L’exposition aux UV peut contribuer, à long terme, au vieillissement prématuré et au cancer de la peau”
“• Suivre les instructions”
“• Porter un dispositif de protection des yeux”
“• Usage déconseillé aux personnes de moins de 18 ans”,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: in the lower left corner, the attribution “Santé Canada — Health Canada” on a white background, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: in the lower right corner, the attribution “Canada” on a white background;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: include in the English version of the label illustrated in Figure 2 of paragraph (e), enclosed within a black border,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the upper portion, on a white background, the signal word “Danger” in red with the hazard symbol to its right,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the middle portion, the primary hazard statement “Tanning Equipment Can Cause Cancer” in yellow on a black background,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the lower left portion, the following statements in black on a white background and in the following order:

Provision.Text: “Ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure can be hazardous to your health:”
“• Overexposure causes skin and eye burns”
“• UV effects are cumulative and may be carcinogenic — greater risks are associated with early and repeated exposure”
“• Risk factors include skin type, photosensitivity and history of skin cancer”
“• Drugs and cosmetics may increase UV effects”,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: in the lower right portion, the following statements in black on a white background and in the following order:

Provision.Text: “In the long term, UV exposure can contribute to premature ageing and skin cancer”
“• Follow instructions”
“• Use protective eyewear”
“• Not recommended for use by those under 18 years of age”,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: in the lower left corner, the attribution “Health Canada — Santé Canada” on a white background, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: in the lower right corner, the attribution “Canada” on a white background;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: measure

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 75 mm high and 200 mm wide, in the case of tanning equipment used for full- or half-body exposure, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 50 mm high and 100 mm wide, in any other case;

Paragraph.Label: (d.1)
Paragraph.Text: be reproduced

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in colours that are as close as possible to the colours in which they are set out in the electronic file referred to in paragraph (a), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: as clearly as possible taking into consideration the method of printing used; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: conform to the following figures:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: The image is the French version of the ultraviolet radiation warning label as described in section 5. The image also includes a hazard symbol in the upper right corner, which is an octagonal sign depicting the outline of a human form being irradiated by a source of ultraviolet radiation represented by lines coming from a point above and to the right of the human form. In the lower left corner is a Canadian flag with the words “Santé Canada” and “Health Canada” to its right. In the lower right corner is the word “Canada” with a Canadian flag above the last letter.
ImageGroup.Caption: Figure 1

ImageGroup.AlternateText: The image is the English version of the ultraviolet radiation warning label as described in section 5. The image also includes a hazard symbol in the upper right corner, which is an octagonal sign depicting the outline of a human form being irradiated by a source of ultraviolet radiation represented by lines coming from a point above and to the right of the human form. In the lower left corner is a Canadian flag with the words “Health Canada” and “Santé Canada” to its right. In the lower right corner is the word “Canada” with a Canadian flag above the last letter.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), all advertising material in relation to tanning equipment must include, in a clearly legible manner, the signal word “Danger”, followed by the attribution “According to Health Canada / Selon Santé Canada”, the primary hazard statement “Tanning Equipment Can Cause Cancer / Les appareils de bronzage peuvent causer le cancer” and the statements set out in subparagraphs 5(b)(iii) and (iv) and 5(c)(iii) and (iv).
Advertising material that is in English or French only must include, in a clearly legible manner,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if it is in French only, the signal word “Danger”, followed by the attribution “Selon Santé Canada”, the primary hazard statement “Les appareils de bronzage peuvent causer le cancer” and the statements set out in subparagraphs 5(b)(iii) and (iv); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if it is in English only, the signal word “Danger”, followed by the attribution “According to Health Canada”, the primary hazard statement “Tanning Equipment Can Cause Cancer” and the statements set out in subparagraphs 5(c)(iii) and (iv).

Section.Text: Every ultraviolet lamp must have a tag, tape or card affixed to it that sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its model designation; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the warning “DANGER — Ultraviolet radiation. Follow instructions. Use only in fixtures equipped with a timer. / DANGER — Rayonnements ultraviolets. Suivre les instructions. À n’utiliser qu’avec un dispositif pourvu d’une minuterie.”.

Section.Text: All controls, meters, lights or other indicators of a piece of tanning equipment must be readily identifiable and clearly labelled to indicate their function.
Every piece of tanning equipment must have the following safety features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a control by which the person being exposed may easily turn off the tanning equipment at any time without disconnecting the electrical plug or removing the ultraviolet lamps; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a timer that meets the functioning standards set out in section 16.

Subsection.Text: Every piece of tanning equipment must have a physical barrier between the ultraviolet lamps and the user that prevents any direct physical contact between the user and the lamps.
In the case of tanning beds, the physical barrier must be constructed of plexiglass or an equivalent material.

Section.Text: Every ultraviolet lamp that is used in tanning equipment must be constructed so that it cannot be inserted and operated in a single-contact medium screw lampholder or a double-contact medium screw lampholder.

Every piece of tanning equipment must be accompanied by a number of sets of protective eyewear at least equal to the maximum number of persons who may, at the same time, be exposed to ultraviolet radiation from the tanning equipment, as recommended by the manufacturer of the equipment.

Every piece of tanning equipment, whether it has its original components or replacement components recommended by the manufacturer, must, under the conditions of use specified by the manufacturer, meet the functioning standards set out in this Part.

Every ultraviolet lamp that is used in tanning equipment must function so that, at any distance and in any direction from the radiation source, the irradiance within the wavelength range from 200 nm to less than 260 nm does not exceed 0.003 of the irradiance within the wavelength range from 260 nm to 320 nm.
Every replacement ultraviolet lamp must function so that the maximum exposure time remains within 10% of the maximum exposure time originally recommended by the manufacturer.
The timer must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be adjustable to preset times and have a maximum timer setting not greater than the maximum exposure time recommended by the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a margin of error not greater than 10% of the maximum timer setting; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: not automatically reset when the tanning equipment emissions have been ended by the timer.

Section.Text: Protective eyewear must have a spectral transmittance that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: not more than 0.001 over the wavelength range from 200 nm to 320 nm;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: not more than 0.01 over the wavelength range from 320 nm to 400 nm; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sufficient over wavelengths greater than 400 nm to enable the user to read the labels and use the control specified in paragraph 9(a).

Subsection.Text: The definitions in this subsection apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: aluminum means aluminum that has a degree of purity of 99.9% or higher and a density of 2.70 g/cm3. (aluminium)
aluminum equivalent means the attenuation equivalent of an object expressed in thickness of aluminum. (équivalent en aluminium)
field emission device means a device in which the emission of electrons from the cathode is due solely to the action of an electric field. (dispositif d’émission par effet de champ)
general purpose radiographic equipment means any stationary equipment other than that used solely for the examination of specific anatomical regions. (appareil de radiographie pour usage général)
loading factor means a factor the value of which influences the X-ray tube load, and includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for diagnostic X-ray equipment, if the X-ray beam is produced by the discharge of the capacitor through an X-ray tube, the X-ray tube voltage and the amount of capacitor charge;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for a field emission device, the X-ray tube voltage and the number of pulses; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for any other diagnostic X-ray equipment, the X-ray tube voltage and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the X-ray tube current and irradiation time, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the current time product. (paramètre de charge)

Definition.Text: mammography equipment means diagnostic X-ray equipment that is used for the examination of breast tissue. (appareil à mammographie)
mobile equipment means, with respect to diagnostic X-ray equipment, equipment that is moved between incidents of use. (appareil mobile)

radiographic equipment means diagnostic X-ray equipment that implements a technique in which the information contained in the X-ray pattern is obtained, recorded and optionally processed. (appareil de radiographie)

radioscopic equipment means diagnostic X-ray equipment that implements a technique in which continuous or periodic sequences of X-ray patterns are produced and simultaneously and continuously displayed in the form of visible images. (appareil de radioscopie)

radioscopic imaging assembly means the combination of components in radioscopic equipment that uses X-ray photons to produce a radioscopic image. These components usually consist of the X-ray image receptor, X-ray image intensifier, equipment housings, interlocks and protective shielding. (système d’imagerie radioscopique)
rectification type means, with respect to diagnostic X-ray equipment, the process by which the X-ray generator converts high voltage to X-ray tube voltage. (type deredressement)
stationary equipment means, with respect to diagnostic X-ray equipment, equipment that is never moved between incidents of use. (appareil fixe)
X-ray image receptor means a device that converts incident X-rays into a visible image or into a form that can be made into a visible image by further transformation. (récepteur d’image radiologique)

Subsection.Text: Unless otherwise defined, words and expressions used in this Part have the same meaning as in the International Electrotechnical Commission Standard entitled Medical radiology — Terminology, Publication 788, First edition, 1984.

Section.Text: The manufacturer must ensure that the following information accompanies each piece of diagnostic X-ray equipment:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the installation instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the address of the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any radiological safety procedures and additional precautions that are necessary because of any unique features of the equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the maintenance instructions necessary to keep the equipment in compliance with the requirements of this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the rated line voltage, the maximum line current and the line voltage regulation for the operation of the equipment at the maximum line current;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the loading factors that constitute the maximum line current condition for the X-ray generator;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: for each X-ray tube assembly,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the nominal focal spot sizes and the method of their determination,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the cooling curves for the anode and for the X-ray tube housing,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the X-ray tube rating charts, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the method by which the focal spot to image receptor distance can be determined using the indicator specified in subparagraph 3(c)(i);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: its duty cycles, rectification type and generator rating;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment is battery powered, the minimum state of charge necessary for it to operate;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the operating range of X-ray tube voltages and the maximum deviation for any selected X-ray tube voltage within that range of values;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment is not operated exclusively in automatic exposure control mode, the accuracy limits of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the controlling timer,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the X-ray tube current, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the current time product;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: where the equipment operates under automatic exposure control, the accuracy limits of that control; and

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the conditions under which the information provided under paragraphs (j) to (l) is valid.

Section.Text: Diagnostic X-ray equipment must display the following information in a manner that is legible, permanent and visible on the specified surfaces:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of the main control panel

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement prohibiting unauthorized use and warning that hazardous X-rays are emitted when the equipment is in operation,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the X-ray warning symbol described in section 4, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: with respect to the X-ray generator,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the name of the manufacturer,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the model designation,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the serial number,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: the date of manufacture, and

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: the country of manufacture;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of the X-ray tube housing, with respect to the X-ray tube assembly,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of the manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the model designation,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the serial number,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the date of installation of the X-ray tube in the X-ray tube housing,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the country of manufacture, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the minimum permanent inherent filtration of the X-ray beam emitted from the X-ray tube assembly, expressed in millimetres of aluminum equivalent at a specified X-ray tube voltage;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of the X-ray tube housing or another suitable structure permanently attached to the X-ray tube housing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an indicator that enables the focal spot to image receptor distance to be determined to within 2% of that distance, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the X-ray tube and the X-ray generator are not located within a common enclosure, marks that clearly indicate the anode and cathode terminals on the X-ray tube housing and on the high-voltage generator; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of any beam limiting device that adds filtration to the X-ray beam, the total permanent filtration deliverable by the beam limiting device, expressed in millimetres of aluminum equivalent at a specified X-ray tube voltage.

Section.Text: The X-ray warning symbol shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be displayed in two contrasting colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be visible and identifiable from a distance of 1 m;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be at least 2 cm high and at least 2 cm wide;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: bear the words “CAUTION: X-RAYS — ATTENTION : RAYONS X”; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: conform to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the following diagram:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: Warning sign, bearing the words “Caution: X-Rays — Attention: Rayons X”, described by an inverted triangle containing a tube with a circle in the middle emitting dashed lines

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: symbol 03-03 in the report of the International Electrotechnical Commission entitled Graphical symbols for electrical equipment in medical practice, Publication 878, 1988, illustrated as follows:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: Warning sign, bearing the graphic of three blades around a circle which represents symbol 03-03 in the report of the International Electrotehcnical Commission entitled Graphical symbols for electrical equipment in medical practice, Publication 878, 1988.

Section.Text: All controls, meters, warning lights and other indicators required by this Part must be clearly labelled as to their function.
Diagnostic X-ray equipment must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if more than one X-ray tube is controlled by one control panel,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a visual indicator on or near each X-ray tube housing that shows that the X-ray tube to which the indicator applies is connected and ready to be energized, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a visual indicator on the control panel that shows which of the X-ray tubes are connected and ready to be energized;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a means, appropriate to the rectification type of the equipment, to compensate for variations in X-ray tube voltage caused by line voltage fluctuations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a visual or audible indicator that warns the operator when the variation in line voltage exceeds the rate set out in subsection 23(2) or a mechanism that, in that event, prevents X-rays from being emitted;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: on the control panel

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a warning light that indicates when the equipment is ready to be energized,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a second warning light that indicates when X-rays are being emitted,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: if an automatic exposure control is provided, a visual indicator showing when that mode of operation is selected, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: if the automatic exposure control mode is not selected or does not exist, controls and visual indicators that enable the operator to select the loading factors before an irradiation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment is battery powered, a visual indicator on the control panel showing whether the battery is adequately charged for the proper operation of the equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a mechanism to initiate and terminate an irradiation;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: an audible signal to indicate the termination of an irradiation;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of equipment other than mammography equipment, if an X-ray source assembly has a permanent inherent filtration of 0.5 mm aluminum equivalent or less, a means to add additional filtration;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment moves around a patient by remote control, an emergency stop switch that immediately terminates both the motion of the equipment and the emission of X-rays;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a beam limiting device; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: for equipment that operates within a range set out in column 1 of an item of the table to this paragraph, radiation filters that result in a measured half-value layer of aluminum of not less than

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for each X-ray tube voltage set out in column 2 of that item, the half-value layer set out in column 3 of that item, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in any other case, the half-value layer obtained by linear interpolation or extrapolation from that table.

row.entry: 50 or more but not more than 70

Subsection.Text: An irradiation switch for diagnostic X-ray equipment must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: permit the emission of X-rays only when the operator exerts continuous pressure on the switch;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a foot switch, prevent the emission of any unintended X-rays when it is overturned; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of mobile equipment, permit the operator to stand at least 3 m from the X-ray source when the X-ray tube is energized.

Subsection.Text: The controlling timer for diagnostic X-ray equipment must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: automatically terminate an irradiation

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: on completion of a preset irradiation time,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on attainment of a preset current time product value, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: on completion of a preset number of X-ray pulses;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: permit the operator to terminate an irradiation at any time;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: automatically reset itself to its original setting or to zero on termination of an irradiation; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: prevent the initiation of irradiation when the timer is set at zero, at the “off” position or at an unmarked setting.

Subsection.Text: In the case of diagnostic X-ray equipment, other than mammography equipment, when an object set out in column 1 of an item of the table to this subsection is positioned between the patient and the X-ray image receptor, the aluminum equivalent of the object shall not exceed the amount set out in column 2 of that item, as determined using an X-ray beam that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is generated at an X-ray tube voltage of 100 kV;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has a maximum X-ray tube voltage ripple of 10%; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has a half-value layer of aluminum of 3.7 mm.

Subsection.Text: In the case of mammography equipment, when an object set out in column 1 of an item of the table to this subsection is positioned between the patient and the X-ray image receptor, the aluminum equivalent of the object shall not exceed the amount set out in column 2 of that item, as determined using an X-ray beam that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is generated at an X-ray tube voltage of 30 kV;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has a maximum X-ray tube voltage ripple of 10%; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has a half-value layer of aluminum of 0.3 mm.
