Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2), any sensor used in automatic exposure control is a part of the X-ray image receptor.

Section.Text: For diagnostic X-ray equipment,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the X-ray tube must be securely affixed to and aligned within the X-ray tube housing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the radiation filters must be securely affixed to the exit port of the X-ray tube housing or beam limiting device, or both; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the X-ray source assembly must maintain its required position or movement without drift or vibration during operation.

Section.Text: Radiographic equipment that is equipped with an automatic exposure control must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the operating X-ray tube voltage is 50 kV or more, a minimum irradiation time capability that does not exceed

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a field emission device that operates in pulse mode, the time equivalent to two pulses, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of any other radiographic equipment, the greater of 1/60 s or the time required to deliver a current time product of 5 mAs;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a means to automatically terminate the irradiation when

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: if the operating X-ray tube voltage is less than 50 kV, the current time product exceeds 1,200 mAs per irradiation, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the operating X-ray tube voltage is 50 kV or more,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the current time product exceeds 600 mAs per irradiation, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the product of the X-ray tube voltage, X-ray tube current and irradiation time exceeds 60 kVAs per irradiation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when an irradiation under automatic exposure control terminates because the limits specified in paragraph (b) have been reached,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a visual indicator or audible signal that warns the operator of the termination, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a reset control that must be activated manually before another irradiation under automatic exposure control can be made.

Subsection.Text: General purpose radiographic equipment must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a beam limiting device that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: permits stepless adjustment of the size of the X-ray field, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: when it is set at the smallest aperture and at a focal spot to image receptor distance of 1 m, has an X-ray field of 5 cm by 5 cm, or less;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an X-ray field indicator that uses light to visually define the X-ray field so that the limits of the X-ray field are visible under the ambient lighting conditions in an X-ray room; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a means by which the operator may

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: determine when the X-ray beam axis is perpendicular to the image receptor plane,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: determine the focal spot to image receptor distance to within 2% of that distance, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: align the centre of the X-ray field with the centre of the image reception area to within 2% of the focal spot to image receptor distance.

Subsection.Text: The X-ray field indicator referred to in paragraph (1)(b) must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: illuminate on average at a minimum of 100 lx when measured from the lesser of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the distance of 1 m from the X-ray source, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the maximum focal spot to image receptor distance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be circumscribed by the beam limiting device;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have as its perimeter the locus of points at which the illumination is one fourth of the maximum illumination in the area; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: when the X-ray beam axis is perpendicular to the image receptor plane, visually define the X-ray field within the following specifications, namely,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the separation between the perimeter of the visually defined field and that of the X-ray field does not exceed 2% of the focal spot to image receptor distance, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the dimensions of the X-ray field are indicated and are accurate to within 2% of the focal spot to image receptor distance.

Subsection.Text: General purpose radiographic equipment that has a positive beam limiting system must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: permit stepless adjustment of the size of the X-ray field;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when it is set at the smallest aperture and at a focal spot to image receptor distance of 1 m, have an X-ray field of 5 cm by 5 cm, or less;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: permit adjustment of the size of the X-ray field to dimensions that are smaller than those of the image reception area;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: under the conditions of operation specified in subsection (2),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: automatically adjust the dimensions of the X-ray field to the dimensions of the image reception area, or to a selected portion of that area, within 5 s after insertion of the image receptor, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: prevent the emission of X-rays until the beam limiting device is manually adjusted so that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the dimensions of the X-ray field do not exceed those of the image reception area, or the selected portion of that area, by more than 3% of the focal spot to image receptor distance, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the sum of the absolute values of the differences in the dimensions of the X-ray field and the image reception area, or the selected portion of that area, does not exceed 4% of the focal spot to image receptor distance; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: automatically revert to one of the requirements set out in paragraph (d) on any change to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the dimensions of the image reception area, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the focal spot to image receptor distance, if the change would result in failure to meet the requirements of paragraph (d).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of paragraph (1)(d), the conditions of operation are as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the image receptor is inserted into a permanently mounted cassette holder;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: neither the length nor the width of the image reception area exceeds 50 cm;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the X-ray beam axis is within 3° of the perpendicular to the image receptor plane;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the X-ray beam axis is within 3° of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the horizontal plane, when the focal spot to image receptor distance is 90 cm or more but not more than 205 cm, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the vertical plane, when the focal spot to image receptor distance is 90 cm or more but not more than 130 cm; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: neither tomography nor stereoscopic radiography is being performed.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 14, radiographic equipment, other than general purpose radiographic or mammography equipment, must have a fixed-aperture beam limiting device that, for the combination of image reception area and focal spot to image receptor distance described in subsection (2),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: permits the centre of the X-ray field to be aligned with the centre of the image reception area to within 2% of the focal spot to image receptor distance; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prevents the X-ray field from extending beyond any edge of the image reception area.

Subsection.Text: The fixed-aperture beam limiting device referred to in subsection (1) must display on its exterior surface a specified focal spot to image receptor distance and the dimensions of its image reception area at that distance.

Section.Text: Mobile radiographic equipment that does not meet the requirements of section 13 must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a beam limiting device that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: permits stepless adjustment of the size of the X-ray field, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: when it is set at the smallest aperture and at a focal spot to image receptor distance of 1 m, has an X-ray field of 5 cm by 5 cm, or less;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an X-ray field indicator referred to in paragraph 11(1)(b) that, when the X-ray beam axis is perpendicular to the image receptor plane, permits the alignment of the edges of the illuminated field with the edges of the X-ray field so that the difference between their edges does not exceed 2% of the focal spot to image receptor distance; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a means to determine the focal spot to image receptor distance to an accuracy of 2% or less of that distance.

Subsection.Text: Mammography equipment must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a beam limiting device that limits the size of the X-ray beam to prevent the X-ray field, at any focal spot to image receptor distance at which the equipment operates, from extending

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: more than 5 mm beyond the edge of the patient support next to the chest wall of the patient, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: more than a distance equivalent to 2% of the focal spot to image receptor distance beyond any other edge of the image reception area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an image receptor supporting device that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has protective shielding that limits the residual radiation in accordance with section 26,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: extends to the patient’s chest wall, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: at every other edge, extends beyond the X-ray field by at least 1% of the focal spot to image receptor distance; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a breast compression device that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is foot-actuated to start the compression,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: permits fine adjustment of motion during the compression,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: permits rapid decompression,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: has motion adjustment controls on both sides of the position for the patient, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: allows the portion of the compression plate in contact with the breast to be brought to within 10 mm of the surface of the patient support.

Subsection.Text: Mammography equipment that has a removable, fixed-aperture beam limiting device must display the following information on its external surface:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the dimensions of the image reception area; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the focal spot to image receptor distance at which the beam limiting device must be used.

Section.Text: Diagnostic X-ray equipment that has a spotfilm device must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the angle of the image receptor plane or of the X-ray source assembly is adjustable by the operator, a means to indicate when the X-ray beam axis is perpendicular to the image receptor plane;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the X-ray beam axis is perpendicular to the image receptor plane, a mechanism that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: when the X-ray field is larger than the selected portion of the image reception area, adjusts the dimensions of the field automatically to those of the selected portion of that area,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: when the X-ray field is smaller than the selected portion of the image reception area, permits the adjustment of the dimensions of the X-ray field,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: permits the perimeter of the X-ray field to be aligned with that of the selected portion of the image reception area so that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the dimensions of the X-ray field differ from the corresponding dimensions of the image reception area by a distance that does not exceed 3% of the focal spot to image receptor distance, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the sum of the absolute values of the differences in the dimensions between the X-ray field size and the image reception area does not exceed 4% of the focal spot to image receptor distance, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: permits the centre of the X-ray field to be aligned with the centre of the selected portion of the image reception area to within 2% of the focal spot to image receptor distance;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a mechanism for adjusting the X-ray field to dimensions that are smaller than those of the selected portion of the image reception area so that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: when the mechanism is set at the smallest aperture and at the longest focal spot to image receptor distance, the X-ray field is 5 cm by 5 cm, or less, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the requirement set out in subparagraph (b)(iv) is met when the X-ray beam axis is perpendicular to the image receptor plane; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if a means is provided for the operator to override a failure of the automatic X-ray field size adjustment, a visual indicator at the operator’s position that shows when the override is activated.

Section.Text: Radiographic equipment, other than equipment described in sections 11 to 16, must have a beam limiting device that, when the axis of the X-ray beam is perpendicular to the image receptor plane, permits

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the alignment of the centre of the X-ray field with the centre of the image reception area to within 2% of the focal spot to image receptor distance; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the adjustment of the perimeter of the X-ray field so that the perimeter does not extend beyond that of the image reception area by more than 2% of the focal spot to image receptor distance.

Section.Text: Radioscopic equipment must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have an X-ray image intensifier that includes protective shielding that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for any focal spot to image receptor distance, intercepts the entire cross section of the X-ray beam,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: intercepts the X-ray beam and scattered radiation from the image intensifier that would otherwise reach the operator,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: prevents the radioscopic X-ray tube from emitting X-rays unless the protective shielding is in place to intercept the X-ray beam, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: sufficiently attenuates the X-rays transmitted through or scattered from the entrance window of the radioscopic imaging assembly to meet the requirements of section 32;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for mobile radioscopic equipment, have an X-ray image intensifier that is an integral part of the equipment or is interlocked in such a manner that its removal prevents X-rays from being produced;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for stationary radioscopic equipment, prevent the X-ray tube from producing X-rays when there is no image receptor in place to intercept the X-ray beam;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for stationary radioscopic equipment that is not equipped with remote control,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: have protective shielding of at least 0.25 mm lead equivalent at 100 kV, such as overlapping hinged or sliding panels or protective drapes, to intercept the scattered radiation that would otherwise reach the operator, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the capability to remove the protective shielding referred to in subparagraph (i) when it interferes with the performance of diagnostic procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: have an irradiation switch that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: requires continuous pressure by the operator for the entire period of an irradiation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: enables the operator to terminate the recording of serial radioscopic images at any time;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: have a chronometer that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: indicates the amount of time that the equipment has been emitting X-rays, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: can be reset to zero or any other selected value;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: have a positive beam limiting system that, when the X-ray beam axis is perpendicular to the image receptor plane, permits the alignment of the perimeter of the illuminated field with that of the X-ray field so that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the difference between the perimeters does not exceed a distance equivalent to 3% of the focal spot to image receptor distance, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the sum of the excess length and excess width does not exceed 4% of the focal spot to image receptor distance;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: have visual indicators that continuously display the X-ray tube voltage and the X-ray tube current; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: have a device that limits the minimum focal spot to skin distance

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for mobile radioscopic equipment, to 30 cm,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for stationary radioscopic equipment, to 38 cm,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: for radioscopic equipment fitted with an X-ray image intensifier and used for special applications that require shorter focal spot to skin distances than the focal spot to skin distances specified in subparagraphs (i) and (ii), to 20 cm, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: for small-format, low-intensity radioscopic equipment, to the distance at which the equipment delivers an air kerma rate of 50 mGy/min or an exposure rate of 5.75 R/min.

Section.Text: Radioscopic equipment that is used for cineradiography must have visual indicators that continuously display the X-ray tube voltage and the X-ray tube current.
A high-level irradiation control for radioscopic equipment must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be activated by a separate means that requires continuous pressure by the operator for it to emit X-rays; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when it is in use, emit a continuous audible signal or an intermittent signal with silent periods of no longer than one second.

Section.Text: Diagnostic X-ray equipment must function in accordance with the requirements set out in sections 22 to 32 during its operation under normal conditions of use.

Subsection.Text: The definitions in this subsection apply in this section.

Definition.Text: coefficient of variation means the ratio of the estimated standard deviation to the mean value of a series of measurements calculated using the equation:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: The coefficient of variation, calculated by the equation “C equals S divided by X bar which is also equal to one divided by x bar multiplied by, open square bracket, sum from i equals one to n, open parenthesis, x sub i minus x bar, close parenthesis, squared, divided by n minus one, close square bracket, to the power of one half”

FormulaDefinition.Text: is the coefficient of variation;
is the estimated standard deviation;
is the value of the ith measurement;
is the mean value of the measurements; and
is the number of measurements. (coefficient de variation)

Definition.Text: exposure to the X-ray image receptor means the amount of X-rays, registered by one or more detectors located in a fixed position in proximity to the X-ray image receptor, that is necessary to produce a radiogram of the overall density sought by the operator. (exposition au récepteur d’image radiologique)

Subsection.Text: For any combination of X-ray tube voltage, X-ray tube current and irradiation time, or for any selected exposure to the X-ray image receptor, when the line voltage for each measurement is accurate to within 1% of the mean line voltage value of all the measurements, and when all variable controls for the loading factors are adjusted to alternate settings and reset to the test setting before each measurement,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the coefficient of variation of any 10 consecutive air kerma or exposure measurements, taken at the same point along the X-ray beam axis within a period of one hour, must be no greater than 0.05; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each of the 10 air kerma or exposure measurements taken under paragraph (a) must be within 15% of the mean value of those measurements.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (2), diagnostic X-ray equipment with an automatic exposure control must have attenuating material in the X-ray beam that is thick enough that the loading factors can be adjusted to provide single irradiations of at least

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 12 pulses, in the case of a field emission device that operates in pulse mode; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 0.1 s, in the case of any other diagnostic X-ray equipment.

Subsection.Text: This section applies in respect of diagnostic X-ray equipment that has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a high-voltage generator that is not a stored energy high-voltage generator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: loading factors that do not change automatically to compensate for unintentional variations in X-ray tube voltage; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an irradiation time of at least 0.1 s and a current time product of at least 5 mAs.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a line voltage regulation of 6% or less, the loading factor set out in column 1 of an item of the table to this subsection must not deviate from the selected value, for any combination of loading factors, by more than the quantity set out in column 2 of that item.

row.entry: Maximum Deviation from the Selected Value
X-ray tube voltage of mammography equipment
X-ray tube voltage of non-mammography equipment

Subsection.Text: The controlling timer or automatic exposure control device of diagnostic X-ray equipment must have a minimum irradiation time capability that does not exceed the greater of:

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the time required to deliver a current time product of 5 mAs.

Subsection.Text: If the automatic exposure control of diagnostic X-ray equipment is selected, the variation in optical density set out in subsection (3) or (4) must be determined using objects that are made of human-tissue equivalent material and have thicknesses that are representative of the actual range of the body thicknesses of the patients.

The automatic exposure control device of diagnostic X-ray equipment, other than mammography equipment, when the X-ray tube voltage and the thickness of the objects described in subsection (2) are held constant or varied as specified in columns 1 and 2 of an item of the table to this subsection, must limit the variation in optical density of the resulting radiograms to the quantity set out in column 3 of that item.

The automatic exposure control device of mammography equipment, when both the X-ray tube voltage and the thickness of the objects described in subsection (2) are varied, must limit the variation in optical density of the resulting radiograms to 0.15.

For any selected value of X-ray tube voltage within a range determined in accordance with subsection (2), the quotients of the average air kerma or exposure measurement divided by the indicated current time product, obtained at the applicable settings specified in subsection (3), must not differ by more than 0.10 times their sum as determined by the formula

FormulaDefinition.Text: is the quotient of the average air kerma or exposure
is the quotient of the average air kerma or exposure measurement divided by the current time product determined at the second of the two applicable settings specified in subsection (3).

Subsection.Text: The range referred to in subsection (1) is the smaller of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 40% to 90% of the maximum available X-ray tube voltage, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the range of X-ray tube voltages specified for the diagnostic X-ray equipment by the manufacturer.

Subsection.Text: The quotients referred to in subsection (1) must be determined at

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the X-ray tube current is selected in discrete steps, any two consecutive X-ray tube current settings;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the X-ray tube current selection is continuous, any two X-ray tube current settings that differ by a factor of 2 or less;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the current time product is selected in discrete steps, any two consecutive current time product settings; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the current time product selection is continuous, any two current time product settings that differ by a factor of 2 or less.

Subsection.Text: If diagnostic X-ray equipment has more than one focal spot, the quotients referred to in subsection (1) must be determined for all combinations of two focal spots that have a nominal focal spot size greater than 0.45 mm, and all combinations of two focal spots that have a nominal focal spot size equal to or less than 0.45 mm at the applicable settings set out in subsection (3).

For mammography equipment, the residual radiation behind the image receptor supporting device must not exceed an air kerma measurement of 1.0 µGy or an exposure measurement of 0.115 mR per irradiation when the equipment is operated at

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its maximum X-ray field and minimum focal spot to image receptor distance; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its maximum X-ray tube voltage and maximum current time product.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the air kerma or exposure measurement must be averaged over a detection area that is 100 cm2, of which no linear dimension is greater than 20 cm, centred at 5 cm from any accessible surface beyond the image receptor supporting device.
Mammography equipment must have a minimum rate of radiation output of 7.0 mGy/s or 802 mR/s when the equipment is operated

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: with a molybdenum anode and molybdenum filter;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with the breast compression device in place between the X-ray source and the detector; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at an X-ray tube voltage of 28 kV in standard mammography mode at any focal spot to image receptor distance.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the minimum rate of radiation output must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: measured at a position that is 4.5 cm above the patient support; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: averaged over a period of irradiation of 3.0 s.

Subsection.Text: Radioscopic equipment that has a feature described in column 1 of an item of the table to this subsection, other than when radioscopic images are being recorded, must not operate at any combination of X-ray tube voltage and X-ray tube current that results in an air kerma rate that exceeds that set out in column 2 of that item or an exposure rate that exceeds that set out in column 3 of that item:

table.title: Maximum Air Kerma or Exposure Rate of Radioscopic Equipment, Other Than When It Is Recording Images

row.entry: Not equipped with an automatic intensity control
Equipped with an automatic intensity control
Equipped with both an automatic intensity control and a high-level irradiation control when the latter is activated

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the air kerma or exposure rate must be determined at a location along the X-ray beam axis that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the X-ray source is below the table, 1 cm above the table;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the X-ray source is above the table, 30 cm above the table and with the X-ray source assembly positioned as closely as possible to the location of the measurement;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment is a C-arm radioscope, 30 cm from the input surface of the radioscopic imaging assembly; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the equipment is a lateral type radioscope, 15 cm from the centre line of the table in the direction of the X-ray source and with the X-ray source assembly positioned as closely as possible to the location of the measurement for all positions of the table.

Subsection.Text: The leakage radiation from the X-ray source assembly of diagnostic X-ray equipment must not exceed an air kerma rate of 1.0 mGy/h or an exposure rate of 115 mR/h when the equipment is operated at the nominal X-ray tube conditions of loading that correspond to the maximum specified energy input in one hour.
For the purposes of subsection (1), the rate must be averaged over a detection area of 100 cm2, of which no linear dimension is greater than 20 cm, that is centred at 1 m from the focal point.

If high voltage can appear across the X-ray tube of the diagnostic X-ray equipment, then the radiation emitting from the X-ray source assembly of the equipment must not exceed an air kerma rate of 20.0 µGy/h or an exposure rate of 2.3 mR/h when

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment is operated with its beam limiting device fully open; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the automatic exposure control or the irradiation switch has not been activated.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the rate must be averaged over a detection area of 10 cm2, of which no linear dimension is greater than 5 cm, that is centred at 5 cm from any accessible surface of the X-ray source assembly.

Under any operating condition, the radiation from any component of diagnostic X-ray equipment, other than the X-ray source assembly, must not exceed an air kerma rate of 20.0 µGy/h or an exposure rate of 2.3 mR/h.

For the purposes of subsection 1, the rate must be averaged over a detection area of 10 cm2, of which no linear dimension is greater than 5 cm, that is centred at 5 cm from any accessible surface of the component.

In the case of radioscopic equipment, the radiation resulting from the transmission of the X-ray beam through, or scattered from, the entrance window of the radioscopic imaging assembly must not exceed an air kerma rate of 2 mGy/h for an entrance air kerma rate of 1 Gy/min or an exposure rate of 2 mR/h for an entrance exposure rate of 1 R/min.
For the purposes of subsection (1), the rate must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: taken at the applicable location specified in subsection 28(2) for the type or configuration of the equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: taken with an attenuation block made of aluminum and having the dimensions 20 cm by 20 cm by 3.8 cm that is positioned between the point of entrance of the radiation and the image reception area of the radioscopic imaging assembly; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: averaged over a detection area of 100 cm 2 that is centred 10 cm from any accessible surface of the radioscopic imaging assembly and in a plane beyond the image receptor.

Section.Text: In this Part and in item 13 of Schedule I,

Definition.Text: amplitude modulated wave means a wave in which the ratio of the temporal maximum pressure amplitude to the root-mean square pressure amplitude, each spatially averaged over the effective radiating surface, is greater than 1.05; (onde modulée en amplitude)
applicator means the part of the ultrasound therapy device designed to transmit ultrasonic power from the transducer to a patient and includes the transducer and any associated housing; (applicateur)

continuous wave means a wave in which the ratio of the temporal maximum pressure amplitude to the root-mean square pressure amplitude, each spatially averaged over the effective radiating surface, is less than or equal to 1.05; (onde entretenue)
control panel means that portion of the external surface of the housing on which the user controls are mounted; (tableau de commande)

effective radiating area means the area of the effective radiating surface that encompasses all points at which the ultrasonic intensity is equal to or greater than five per cent of the maximum spatial ultrasonic intensity at the effective radiating surface, expressed in square centimetres (cm2); (aire émettrice utile)
effective radiating surface means the surface covering all points that are 5 mm from the applicator face; (surface émettrice utile)
effective ultrasonic intensity, with respect to ultrasonic power, means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a focussing applicator, the quotient obtained by dividing the amount of the ultrasonic power by the amount of the focal area, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, the quotient obtained by dividing the amount of the ultrasonic power by the amount of the effective radiating area; (intensité ultrasonore utile)

Definition.Text: focal area means the area of the focal surface expressed in square centimetres (cm2); (aire focale)
focal length in respect of a focussing applicator, means the distance in centimetres between

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that point of the effective radiating surface the coordinates of which are the mean values of the coordinates of the points of that surface, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that point of the focal surface the coordinates of which are the mean values of the coordinates of the points of that surface; (longueur focale)

Definition.Text: focal surface in respect of a focussing applicator, means the beam cross-section with the smallest area; (surface focale)

focussing applicator means an applicator in which the quotient of the area of the surface having the smallest area, in any plane consisting of the points at which the ultrasonic intensity is greater than five per cent of the maximum intensity in that plane, and the effective radiating area is less than one-half; (applicateur focalisant)
housing means a structure that encloses

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that portion of a fully assembled ultrasound therapy device that supplies the electrical energy to the applicator, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the electrical circuitry of the device; (logement)

Definition.Text: pressure amplitude means the instantaneous value of the modulating waveform in the following equation:

FormulaDefinition.Text: is the instantaneous pressure,
is the modulating wave form,
is the relative amplitude of the carrier wave normalized to a peak height of one,
are periodic functions of time, t, at any point in space, and
is greater than the period p2(t);

Provision.Text: (amplitude de pression)

Definition.Text: pulse duration means a time interval, expressed in seconds, beginning at the first time the pressure amplitude exceeds the value that equals the sum of the minimum pressure amplitude and 10 per cent of the difference between the maximum and minimum pressure amplitudes and ending at the last time the pressure amplitude returns to that value; (durée des impulsions)
pulse repetition rate means the repetition frequency of the wave shape that modulates the ultrasonic radiation carrier wave expressed in pulses per second (pps); (taux de répétition des impulsions)
service controls means controls provided by the manufacturer for adjusting the ultrasound therapy device that, under normal conditions of use, are not accessible to the user; (commandes internes)
ultrasonic frequency means the frequency of the ultrasonic power wave, expressed in kilohertz (kHz) or megahertz (mHz); (fréquence)

ultrasonic power means the total power that is emitted in the form of ultrasonic radiation by the applicator and that is averaged over each cycle of the ultrasonic radiation carrier wave, expressed in watts (W); (puissance acoustique)
user controls means controls provided by the manufacturer for operating the ultrasound therapy device that, under normal conditions of use, are accessible to the user. (commandes externes)

Subsection.Text: Every ultrasound therapy device shall be designed and constructed in such a manner that, under the conditions of use specified by the manufacturer, it functions in accordance with section 3 for as long as the device has its original components or replacement components recommended by the manufacturer.
Every ultrasound therapy device shall be designed in such a manner that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all marks, labels and signs are permanently affixed thereon and clearly visible; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all user controls, meters, lights or other indicators are clearly visible, readily discernible and clearly labelled to indicate their function.

Subsection.Text: Every ultrasound therapy device shall bear

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of its housing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and address of the manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and address of the distributor, if the distributor is not the manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the type and model designation,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the serial number,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the month and year of manufacture,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the ultrasonic frequencies in kilohertz (kHz) or megahertz (mHz),

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: a statement indicating whether the wave produced by the device is a continuous wave or an amplitude modulated wave,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a device that produces an amplitude modulated wave,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the pulse repetition rate, the pulse duration, the ratio of the temporal maximum effective ultrasonic intensity to the temporal average effective ultrasonic intensity, and a description of the wave shape, where these parameters do not vary depending on the power, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the pulse repetition rate, the pulse duration, the ratio of the temporal maximum effective ultrasonic intensity to the temporal average effective ultrasonic intensity, and a description of the wave shape, all at temporal maximum ultrasonic power where these parameters do vary depending on the power,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: the line voltage used for normal operation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: the ultrasound radiation warning sign described in section 4; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of each applicator

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the identification of the type and model of the ultrasound therapy device for which it is designed,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where an applicator is a focussing applicator, the focal length and the focal area,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a unique serial number or other unique identification, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the effective radiating area in square centimetres (cm2).

Subsection.Text: Every ultrasound therapy device shall be designed and constructed to include the following safety features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the control panel, separate indicator lights or other equivalent indicators that have an expected lifetime of at least 5000 hours,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to show when the line voltage is “ON” or “OFF”, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to show when the ultrasonic power is being applied to the applicator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a power indicator that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a device that produces a continuous wave, shows by a direct reading the level of the temporal average ultrasonic power and the temporal average effective ultrasonic intensity,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a device that produces an amplitude modulated wave, shows by a direct reading the level of the temporal maximum ultrasonic power and the temporal maximum effective ultrasonic intensity, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: functions in accordance with section 3;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a clear and reliable indicator of the range used, if the power indicator described in paragraph (b) utilizes two or more different ranges of measurement; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a timer that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: terminates the generation of ultrasound after a preset time interval and then returns to zero,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: does not allow the generation of ultrasound with the timer set at zero,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is adjustable to settings in increments not greater than one minute, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: functions in accordance with section 3.

Subsection.Text: Where an ultrasound therapy device is equipped with an ultrasonic power control, that control shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: allow the adjustment of ultrasonic power;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a minimum and maximum adjustment that directly relates to the ultrasonic power level indicator; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: function in accordance with section 3.

Subsection.Text: Every ultrasound therapy device shall function in such a manner that when the device is operating with its user controls adjusted to yield the maximum temporal average-spatial average effective ultrasonic intensity, such intensity shall not exceed 3 W/cm2, when measured in accordance with subsection (2).
The method used to measure the effective ultrasonic intensity for the purposes of subsection (1) shall produce a result that is at least as accurate as the result that would be produced by using

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an ultrasound balance radiometer to measure the ultrasonic power; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an ultrasound detector of dimensions less than one wavelength in water to measure the pulse repetition rate, the pulse duration and the effective radiating area.

Subsection.Text: The power indicator referred to in paragraph 2(4)(b) shall show on the scale of the ultrasonic power control or on the output power meter the ultrasonic power with an accuracy of ±20 per cent when the output is greater than 10 per cent of the maximum ultrasonic power.

The timer referred to in paragraph 2(4)(d) shall be accurate to within 30 seconds for settings less than five minutes, to within 10 per cent for settings from five to 10 minutes, and to within one minute for settings greater than 10 minutes.

The ultrasonic power output shall remain constant within ±20 per cent of its initial value during one hour of continuous operation, at maximum output and at rated supply line voltage, in water at a temperature of 22°C ± 3°C.

The actual ultrasonic frequency of an ultrasound therapy device shall not differ more than ±5% from the ultrasonic frequency of the device that is stated on the external surface of the housing of the device pursuant to subparagraph 2(3)(a)(vi).
The effective radiating area shall be kept within ±20 per cent of the rated value given by the manufacturer.

Section.Text: The warning sign referred to in subparagraph 2(3)(a)(x) is a sign that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is shown in two contrasting colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly visible and identifiable from a distance of 1 m;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has no outer dimensions less than 2 cm;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: bears the words “CAUTION-ULTRASOUND, ATTENTION-ULTRASONS”; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is designed in accordance with the following diagram:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: Warning sign, bearing the words “CAUTION-ULTRASOUND, ATTENTION-ULTRASONS”, described by an inverted triangle containing a small rectangle with a curled line attached in the right corner emitting a series of lines

Section.Text: The definitions in this section apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: accessory means any component used on analytical X-ray equipment in order to enable the equipment to perform its intended use, to adapt the equipment to some special purpose, to facilitate use of the equipment, to enhance the performance of the equipment or to enable the function of the equipment to be integrated with that of other equipment. (accessoire)
beam-limiting device means a device that limits the dimensions of a radiation beam. (dispositif de limitation du faisceau)
control panel means that part of analytical X-ray equipment on which are mounted

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one or more manually-operated controls that regulate all, or some, of the functions of the equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meters, lights or other indicators that disclose operating factors and conditions. (poste de commande)

Definition.Text: high-voltage generator means a combination of the components necessary for the production and control of the electrical energy to be supplied to an X-ray tube, which components usually consist of a high-voltage transformer assembly and a control assembly. (générateur radiologique)
interlock means a system that prevents the start or the continued operation of equipment unless certain predetermined conditions prevail. (verrouillage)
protective shielding means material that limits the extent of a radiation beam or attenuates stray radiation. (barrière de protection radiologique)
radiation aperture means an aperture in the protective shielding of a radiation source or a beam-limiting device, that is intended to give passage to the radiation beam. (fenêtre)

radiation beam means a spatial region that is limited in solid angle and that contains a flux of ionizing radiation which originates from a radiation source that is considered a point source. (faisceau de rayonnement)
shutter means a mechanism that opens or closes a radiation aperture to enable or prevent the passage of a radiation beam. (obturateur)

stray radiation means all ionizing radiation except that of the specified radiation beam under consideration, but includes that part of the radiation beam which emerges from the material being irradiated. (rayonnement parasite)
timing device means a device that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: integrates or presents the time elapsed during an equipment function; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: changes the state of operation at the end of a predetermined time interval. (intégrateur de temps)

Section.Text: Analytical X-ray equipment shall be designed and constructed in such a manner that, when installed, operated and maintained in accordance with the instructions referred to in paragraph 3(a), it functions in accordance with section 10.
Analytical X-ray equipment shall be accompanied by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: instructions from the manufacturer as to the installation, interconnection, testing, operation and maintenance of the equipment and its accessories and replacement components; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: information from the manufacturer on the recommended accessories and replacement components.

Section.Text: Analytical X-ray equipment shall bear on the control panel, next to any one switch that turns on an X-ray tube, each of the following labels:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a label bearing an X-radiation warning symbol that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is displayed in two contrasting colours,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is clearly visible and readily discernible from a distance of 1 m,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: has no outer dimension that is less than 2 cm,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: bears the words “CAUTION: X-RADIATION — ATTENTION : RAYONNEMENTS X”, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: conforms to the following diagram, namely,

ImageGroup.AlternateText: Warning sign, bearing the words “Caution: X-Rays — Attention: Rayons X”, described by an inverted triangle containing a tube with a circle in the middle emitting dashed lines

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a label bearing the words

Provision.Text: “CAUTION — X-RADIATION. This Equipment Produces High Intensity X-radiation When Energized. To be Operated Only by Qualified Personnel.
ATTENTION — RAYONNEMENTS X. Cet appareil produit des rayonnements X haute intensité lorsqu’il est sous tension. Son utilisation est réservée au personnel compétent;” and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a label setting out

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and address of the manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the model designation,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the serial number,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the date of manufacture, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the country of manufacture.

Section.Text: Analytical X-ray equipment shall be designed and constructed in such a manner that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all labels required by this Part are securely affixed to the equipment and clearly visible;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all controls, meters, lights and other indicators required by this Part are readily discernible and clearly labelled as to function;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the X-ray tube housing, shutters, beam-limiting devices, couplings and protective shielding will not deform or their shielding properties deteriorate;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: when the equipment is assembled, the radiation beam is contained within protective shielding that is equipped with an interlock; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where a radiation aperture must be open in order to set up or align the equipment, a visual and an aural indicator warns the operator that the radiation aperture is open for the duration that it is open.

Section.Text: Analytical X-ray equipment shall be designed and constructed to include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a control panel that regulates one or more X-ray tubes and that includes

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an “ON/OFF” switch equipped with warning lights that indicate when the control panel is energized,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a key-actuated control that prevents X-radiation production with the key removed,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an “ON/OFF” X-radiation switch for each X-ray tube, equipped with a warning light that indicates when X-radiation is being produced,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: indicators or meters that identify which X-ray tube is being used and the corresponding applied X-ray tube voltage and X-ray tube current, unless this information is provided on an accessory,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a warning light for each X-ray tube that indicates when any shutter on that tube is open, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: a timing device for each X-ray tube, unless the device is a component of an accessory;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for each radiation aperture, a shutter that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: remains closed when not in use,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: requires the operator to open it manually or by means of a computer controlled function,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is equipped with an interlock in its operating mechanism, unless an alignment device or accessory is integrated into the radiation aperture and that alignment device or accessory is equipped with an interlock,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: can be removed only with special tools, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: is designed with protective shielding;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: labyrinth-type joints, couplings or interfaces between radiation apertures, shutters, protective shielding, beam-limiting devices and accessories; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the equipment is designed for use with interchangeable filters,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: interlocks or other means to ensure that insertion or removal of those filters is possible only when X-radiation is not being produced, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: filter slots that are covered by protective shielding when they are not in use.

Section.Text: Every accessory supplied by a manufacturer shall be accompanied by information that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sets out the specific analytical X-ray equipment for which the accessory is designed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: indicates the design and specifications of the couplings, fittings, interfaces and parts that are necessary for the installation and functioning of that accessory.

Section.Text: Every accessory associated with the production, collimation, transmission or detection of X-radiation shall bear on its external surface a label that sets out, in respect of that accessory,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the model designation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the serial number;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date of manufacture; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the country of manufacture.

Section.Text: Every accessory associated with the production, collimation, transmission or detection of X-radiation shall be designed and constructed in such a manner that it is contained within protective shielding that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prevents the radiation beam from touching any part of the operator’s body; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is equipped with an interlock.

Section.Text: Assembled analytical X-ray equipment, when operated at any of its designed X-ray tube voltage and X-ray tube current specifications, shall function in such a way that the X-radiation emitted does not exceed 0.5 milliroentgen (≈4.38 microgray air kerma) in one hour at a distance of 5 cm from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any accessible external surfaces of any X-ray tube housing, beam-limiting device, protective shielding or accessory;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any radiation aperture, shutter or filter slot that is in the closed position; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any point on the housing of the high-voltage generator.

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: cabinet means an enclosure that, independent of existing structures, contains the X-ray generator, detectors and space for the material to be examined, provides radiation attenuation and prevents access to the X-ray beam; (enceinte)

central processing unit means that part of the electronic circuitry that receives signals from the X-ray detection system and subsequently causes an action to be taken on the material being examined; (unité centrale)
control panel means the control panel referred to in paragraph 7(a) of this Part; (tableau de commande)
detector means the image receptor or other device that intereacts with the X-rays to produce a signal corresponding to the intensity of the X-rays incident on it; (détecteur)
material means any substance, object or product subjected to X-ray irradiation for the purpose of obtaining information about that substance, object or product; (matière)

model designation means any combination of letters or figures or both letters and figures by which a device that bears that designation is identified as having characteristics and design features that are uniform; (désignation du modèle)
primary X-ray beam means that X-radiation emitted directly from the target of the X-ray tube and emerging from the port of the X-ray tube housing; (faisceau primaire de rayons X)
X-ray generator means an assembly of components, including an X-ray tube and its housing and shielding, designed and constructed for the controlled generation of X-rays. (producteur de rayons X)

Section.Text: Cabinet X-ray equipment shall be designed and constructed in such a manner that, when installed and maintained in accordance with the instructions referred to in section 3, it functions within the standards of functioning described in section 10 for as long as the device has its original components or has replacement components recommended by the manufacturer.

Cabinet X-ray equipment shall be equipped with installation and maintenance instructions furnished by the manufacturer of the device that, if followed, will enable the device to function within the requirements of this Part.
Cabinet X-ray equipment shall bear

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of the X-ray control panel,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a warning sign, next to the X-rays “ON” switch, that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: indicates the possibility of hazardous radiation emission when the device is in operation, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: prohibits unauthorized use,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the X-radiation warning sign described in section 11, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a permanent mark or label that sets out, in respect of the device,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the name of the manufacturer,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the model designation,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the serial number,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: the date of manufacture, and

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: the city and country of manufacture; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on the external surface of all doors or panels through which material to be X-rayed is inserted into or removed from the device, the X-radiation warning sign described in section 11.

Section.Text: Cabinet X-ray equipment shall be designed and constructed in such a manner that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all marks, labels and signs required by this Part are securely affixed to the device and are clearly visible and readily discernible; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all controls, meters, lights or other indicators required by this Part are readily discernible and clearly labelled or marked with respect to function.

Section.Text: Cabinet X-ray equipment shall have sufficient shielding to enable the device to function within the standards of functioning described in section 10.
Cabinet X-ray equipment shall be designed and constructed to include the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a control panel having the following safety features:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a power “ON/OFF” switch,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a lock of a type that requires the insertion of a key before X-rays can be produced and the removal of the key to terminate production of X-rays,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a warning light that indicates when the power is “ON”,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a warning light, in addition to the warning light referred to in subparagraph (iii), that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: indicates when X-rays are being generated,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: where the device is designed to operate with a pulsed X-ray beam, is activated for at least one-half second, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: unless there is a warning light or other indicator referred to in subparagraph (v) incorporated on the control panel, is connected and interlocked in such a manner that X-rays cannot be produced if the warning light malfunctions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: unless the warning light referred to in subparagraph (iv) is connected and interlocked in the manner described in clause (iv)(C), a warning light or other indicator that duplicates the functions of the warning light referred to in subparagraph (iv) whose function is not affected if the warning light referred to in that subparagraph malfunctions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shielded doors or panels over all access openings designed for insertion or removal of any material to be examined except where the design of the device prevents the insertion of any part of the human body into the primary X-ray beam;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: safety features connecting and interlocking each of the doors and panels referred to in paragraph (b) with at least two independent interlocks to prevent the generation of X-rays if any door or panel is open;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: interlocks on all doors and panels, other than those doors and panels referred to in paragraph (b), that allow access to areas inside the cabinet where the exposure rate to X-rays may exceed 0.5 milliroentgen per hour to prevent the generation of X-rays if any door or panel is opened or removed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: subject to section 8, one or more controls that require separate operator action to initiate each X-ray exposure; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a beam limiting device that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: ensures that the primary X-ray beam is aligned with the X-ray detector, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: restricts the size of the primary X-ray beam, at the plane of the X-ray detector, so that it does not exceed the maximum size of the detector.

Section.Text: Paragraph 7(e) does not apply to cabinet X-ray equipment that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: contains a conveyor or other automatic feed system for insertion and removal of material to be examined where the X-ray exposure or sequence of X-ray exposures is initiated automatically by means of a photocell or other material sensing device; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is designed and constructed to include the following additional safety features:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: where the device requires the continuous presence of an operator during any examination of material, a control or switch of a type that

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: requires continuous pressure by the operator to maintain automatic operation of the device, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: when released, terminates the X-ray exposure or sequence of exposures and stops the conveyor or other automatic feed system,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the device is controlled by a central processing unit and does not require the continuous presence of an operator during any examination of material, provision in the circuitry of the device for the connection of

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: a remote warning light to indicate when X-rays are being generated, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: a control or switch to stop the conveyor or other automatic feed system and terminate the X-ray exposure or sequence of X-ray exposures from a location other than the control panel, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a conveyor or other automatic feed system of sufficient length to prevent the insertion of any part of the human body into any area of the device where the exposure to X-rays exceeds 0.5 milliroentgen per hour.

Section.Text: Cabinet X-ray equipment that is designed to permit the entry of a person shall be designed and constructed to include the following additional safety features:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a switch or control within the cabinet that, when activated,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: prevents X-rays from being generated, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: cannot be reset, by-passed or overriden from the control panel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: controls for initiating X-ray generation that are external to the cabinet and that make it impossible for the initiation of X-ray generation from within the cabinet;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where any optical or image-monitoring equipment is used within the cabinet and fluoroscopy alignment is required, a control device external to the cabinet designed to remotely focus the device;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an audible and visible warning signal within the cabinet that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is activated for at least ten seconds immediately prior to initiation of X-ray generation after the closing of any door that is designed to permit human access into the cabinet, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is connected in such a way that failure or malfunction of any single component in the device does not cause a simultaneous failure of both the audible and visible warning signal; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a warning light within the cabinet that, when X-rays are being produced,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: remains on continuously, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where the X-ray generation period is one-half second or less, remains on for at least one-half second.

Section.Text: Cabinet X-ray equipment, when fully assembled for use, shall function in such a way that, under all possible operating conditions of X-ray generation and at the maximum possible material handling rate specified by the manufacturer, the exposure rate from leakage radiation, averaged over a time period that is not less than five minutes, does not exceed 0.5 milliroentgen per hour at a distance of five centimetres from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any accessible external surface of the device, including the shielded doors or panels referred to in paragraph 7(b), and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the design of the device prevents the insertion of any part of the human body into the primary X-ray beam, an imaginary plane surface that is drawn to close those access openings referred to in paragraph 7(b),

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: when averaged over a detection area of ten square centimetres.

Section.Text: The X-radiation warning sign referred to in section 4 is a sign that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is shown in two contrasting colours;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is clearly visible and identifiable from a distance of one metre;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has no outer dimensions less than two centimetres;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: bears the words “CAUTION, X-RAYS” and “ATTENTION, RAYONS X”; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: is designed in accordance with the following diagram:

ImageGroup.AlternateText: Warning sign, bearing the words “Caution: X-Rays — Attention: Rayons X”, described by an inverted triangle containing a tube with a circle in the middle emitting dashed lines

Section.Text: The Radiation Emitting Devices Regulations, as they read immediately before the date of the coming into force of these Regulations, continue to apply in respect of dental X-ray equipment that was manufactured before the day on which these Regulations come into force.
